Love it

This game is a cooperative zombie survival game. From intense zombie-killing action to perfectly balanced gameplay mechanics, every moment is an adrenaline-pumping thrill ride. The teamwork required to survive adds a new level of excitement, fostering friendship and unforgettable memories with friends. The level design is amazing, you can choose how difficult the enemies you want to play, it offers a variety of environments that keep the experience fresh and interesting, and the workshop is still actively updated for new content. With its timeless appeal and endless replay value, Left 4 Dead is a fun game to play with friends and family, the graphics are so charming at the time that this game became popular.

Recommended to play 4/5

Summary:
Left 4 Dead is a cooperative first-person shooter video game developed by Valve Corporation. Released in 2008, the game focuses on a group of four survivors who must navigate through various levels filled with hordes of zombie-like infected creatures. Players can choose to play as one of the four characters, each with unique personalities and abilities.

The game is divided into several campaigns, each consisting of multiple chapters that present different environments and challenges. The survivors must work together to reach safe houses while battling the infected and special infected mutants with unique abilities.

One of the standout features of Left 4 Dead is its AI Director, a dynamic system that adjusts the difficulty and pacing based on the players' performance. This ensures a dynamic and unpredictable gameplay experience with each playthrough.

Left 4 Dead emphasizes teamwork, communication, and strategic coordination among players to successfully overcome the hordes of infected and complete the objectives. The game received critical acclaim for its innovative cooperative gameplay, intense atmosphere, and replayability.

OVERVIEW: A innovative and action packed FPS survival title that for its time was the best you could buy within its peers. The ability to play it with 3 other friends is a good example of a benchmark for the future of the genre, not to mention the possibility to add mods and, through it, extend its replayability value. A true VALVE gem


Pros
-¬ª Gameplay: There is a nice array of weapons to pick from: pistols, shotguns, axes...you name it
-¬ª Soundtrack and sound effects: gloomy and convincing for the context
-¬ª Graphics: a plus amongst all brackets to consider, adding to the feel and pace of the story till the final chapter
-¬ª Replayability: very interesting if you aim to collect all steam achievements, have online merit or play its harder iterations
-¬ª Difficulty: Suitable for newcomers to the genre
Cons
-¬ª If you compare the quality of the game to its sequel, there isn't much you could complain. LFD is already a great installement to the series

SUMMARY:
8.8/10 gaming scale

Left 4 Dead , while not as great as Left 4 Dead 2 , stands it's grounds pretty well. In Retrospective , Left 4 Dead is one of those first zombie shooters that revolutionized the genre and brought the intensity of 28 Days Later to video games. 

Atmospherically beautiful , even to this day , with a great cast and memorable set pieces , Left 4 Dead was truly one of the best. 

Unfortunately or fortunately (depending on you) , the sequel already consists of everything this game had to offer , with even more stuff you check out and an improved gameplay. 

Still , Left 4 Dead deserves nothing but respect and a veteran's discount for it's innovative and inspiring design.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

One of my all time favourite games and a must play for any zombie survival enthusiasts!

Surprisingly has me playing longer than Payday which I wrote an entire god damn brick wall of text on just because of how good it was, Deft 4 Dead is an amazing franchise and an even better game, and I cannot wait to buy Left 4 Dead 2.

The servers :
Mainly friendly, a few people who don't understand how to play here and there, but many of them are skilled and willing to keep retrying and helping you if you die.
The people are fun to chat and hang out with and while they may not talk much, they are very active.
There is also at least 1 server you can play at all times, I have only played for 7.7 hours across 2 days, but there is at least 10 or so servers every time.

The characters :
Lovable, a lot more personality than games like Payday or Half-Life, even though those games are cool as hell, games which i also recommend, but aside from that the characters designs are iconic too, i'd say the L4D2 characters are more iconic but that's only because that one still gets updated.

[h1]4 Survivors And The Apocalypse[/h1] 
Left 4 Dead is a 2008 first-person shooter game developed by Valve South and published by Valve.Set during the aftermath of a zombie outbreak on the East Coast of the United States, the game pits its four protagonists, dubbed the "Survivors", against hordes of the infected.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üíæGraphics[/td]
        [td]The graphics are pretty good for a 2008 game. Left 4 Dead has more of a charm compared to its Left 4 Dead 2 counterpart. The levels look really atmospheric and scary. The UI is really nice in this game, and I actually prefer this one over Left 4 Dead 2. The game runs really nice and had no crashes or stutters while playing this. Also the characters movement feels more ‚Äúfluid and smooth‚Äù compared to Left 4 Dead 2, it‚Äôs hard to explain so take that how you want.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéÆGameplay[/td]
        [td]The gameplay was really unique when this game came out. Four survivors going against hordes of zombies and special infected that feel truly unique makes this game just so addicting to play. With a great amount of weapons and likable characters, I never got tired of hearing the characters' dialogue. If you die in game, you will respawn in a closet so you have to rely on your friends to get you out, or just wait until the next level as you will respawn back. The versus mode is really fun and if you have a part of eight players, well prepare for a long night of fun. I used to play this game on xbox 360 back on release with friends and we always played this game. It has a memorable place in my heart so I may be a bit biased when I say it's one of the best games ever made. Now if you are picking between Left 4 Dead or Left 4 Dead 2, honestly I would be Left 4 Dead 2. Okay now hear me out, Left 4 Dead 2 already has all the campaigns that Left 4 Dead has, and also steam workshop. I just find it hard to give a reason to go back into this game. Now if you are looking to bring in that nostalgia or curious about the original, you won‚Äôt be disappointed.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üé≠Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]Now the multiplayer is where the game truly shines. You have Co-op and PVP in this game. Let‚Äôs start with the Co-op. You have different game modes, starting from Campaign, Realism, Scavenge and Survival. I mainly played Campaign and some survival and they are both amazing game modes. Realism mode is basically like a hardcore Campaign mode. So you have a good bit of fun with the Singleplayer/Co-op modes. Also Mods work for Campaign mode as well if you play Co-op. Versus mode is really fun as well. It‚Äôs a 8 player game mode where you have 4 survivors, and 4 infected players. You win based on how fast you make it to the safehouse, distance, etc. It‚Äôs a fun chill gamemode with friends, but can be pretty toxic with randoms from my experience.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üïõPlaytime[/td]
        [td]Left 4 Dead has pretty good playtime. The versus mode is absolutely fun, the campaigns are incredible and the gameplay is addicting. If you have any friends that love a good classic, you will add many hours into this game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéßSound[/td]
        [td]I love the sound design in this game. Now I‚Äôm not talking about the music, as the music is not like some Resident Evil save theme material, but the audio queues you get, for example a hunter has a specific audio queue. Hordes have a specific audio, every enemy does. Now the Tank (basically the boss) has its own theme and it's really good. The gun sounds good and not cheesy or lazy, the melee weapons have a good punch to them when you hit a zombie. It's all good and I see no issues at all.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùóBugs‚ùó[/td]
        [td]Every game has some sort of bugs even though you may not ‚Äúsee them‚Äù or experience them. I haven‚Äôt really had any issues in this game. The AI are pretty ‚Äúspecial‚Äù in their pathing and trying to help you get up from nearly dying. I wouldn‚Äôt trust the AI to do much of anything besides heal you.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîÖPerformance[/td]
        [td]This game runs absolutely flawlessly. I had no stutters, crashes, frame drops, etc.You will be able to run this game with no problem at all.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚úîÔ∏èPro‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Unique enemies
[*]addicting PVP
[*]Fun game modes
[*]Scary atmosphere
[*]Amazing sound design
[*]Incredible level design
[*]Balanced gameplay
[*]Huge hordes of zombies
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùåCon‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]AI can be dumb at times
[*]Co-op can be pretty easy
[*]Content can get repetitive after a while
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üèÜRating[/td]
        [td]8.5/10
Get this game at full price if you are absolutely in need of it. It‚Äôs worth the price but if you see a sale that would be a good choice too.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîóConclusion[/td]

Campaign / Base Game
The campaign is extremely fun, at times it does feel a little repetitive, especially when your are playing with bots. None the less, it is an amazing game when it comes down to the unique gun play, interesting characters, and the special infected to spice it up.

Versus Mode
Versus mode really got me to understand the true potential of this game. Granted, sometimes it takes a really long time to get into matches due to this being the lesser game in the franchise. But being able to play as the special infected really brings a whole other level to this game. What makes versus mode shine is all the coordination and strategy involved in it. Going in alone as an infected is never an option which brings in the strategic play of all the coordination. In matter a fact, I'd argue that the game is partially cared by this remarkable game mode.

Complaints
My only complaint is that the game ends up crashing with an 'OUT OF MEMORY' warning often enough to the point where It's irritating and at the end of levels I have to just start praying that my game doesn't crash.

Rating
Left 4 Dead is quite the classic, and still holds up well to this day. It goes on sale often for a $1, regardless, $10 is still worth the price, so if you haven't played you should certainly get it when it's on sale. If it weren't for the crashing this game would be a 10/10 in my book, but considering the fact that is happens often enough my honest rating would be a 9.2/10.

"FRANCIS!" -bill

Other than some of the official servers preforming a little oddly, I find the comments claiming that Left 4 Dead 2 now overshadows its predecessor, given the L4D1 campaigns are available in L4D2, to be a little dismissive, and almost disingenuous to what L4D1 does in its scope.

Left 4 Dead 1 is much more thematically horrific, providing an ambiance that's hard to replicate in a game of its nature. I find you have to play L4D1 a little more calculative-ly than L4D2, given you aren't provided as crazy of a kit as you are in L4D2, adding to the heavy horrific air that clouds over L4D1s campaigns. I love the audio design, the OSTs gentle but progressive sound keeping a tempo as you struggle, versus L4D2 where you slaughter. A lot more things in L4D1 have this sort of weight, on your senses, and in the gameplay itself, giving it some differences to the pacing and tempo that L4D2 has.

There's a mountain of love and polish that's loud and bluntly present in this game. From how infected behave and react to the environment, to the voice acting and how expressive and lively the cast are whilst fighting perilously against hordes upon hordes of common and special infected, to the various 'chemistries' (I'm inventing a word just for this), the cast themselves share between one another... I could ramble on and on. The map design feels like it was actively played and transformed, with L4D1 having my favorite finale out of all the campaigns, being Blood Harvest.

I'd argue to anyone, even on its own or if you've played Left 4 Dead 2, that Left 4 Dead 1 is a must. It doesn't overstay its welcome anywhere, and is a showcase of a Valve that once experimented with unique ways to evolve their own tech, and formulas, in a focused, condensed, tense and terrifying experience that feels fresh to play decades later.

You're on crack if you think L4D2 is easier

Here's how to win

- Open the game
- Choose quickplay
- Nobody's online, so you need to make a server instead
- Start the match
- Kill the 1 special infected the director spawns for the entire chapter
- Hold M2 and walk to the safe room
- Find T2 weapons at the start of chapter 2
- Choose the autoshotgun because it outclasses every other gun
- Follow the main path to the safe room because there's no reason to look for supplies
- Kill the tank in 5 seconds because the autoshotgun is broken
- Ignore the witch because she can't move
- When a horde comes, hold M2
- Find some grenades
- Choose the pipe bomb, because the molotov is useless
- Never use the pipe bomb because all horde events can be beaten by holding M2
- Come across a running crescendo event
- Treat it as a hold your ground crescendo event instead
- Hold M2, wait until the event ends
- Wait as the director spawns the special infected one at a time so you can kill them easily
- Reach the finale
- Start it, hold M2
- Beat the campaign on Expert

I found Left4Dead to be very very over rated. 
Ok, I liked the suspense, the thrill when you begin to play this apocalyptic game, which derives from the dark gloomy survival atmosphere and the zombie hordes that rush at you. But that feeling of tension lasts only 3,4 hours.  
Then you understand the biggest downside of this game: 
1) it's incredibly repetitive. All the missions are the same. Kill the zombies - the regular ones and the 4 special types (smoker, hunter, boomer and tank) and endure the hordes that spawn every minute. And of course get to the safe zone. 
2) The maps feel empty, and not very interactive (not much to destroy or blow up). 
3) There isn't anything to buy, upgrade or build (for example, why not having the possibility to build some defense system like walls, spikes, traps etc...?).
4) The environment is way too dark. I understand that it's a post-apocalyptic game and that the power went out everywhere. But still.....it is annoying to have to plow through all those dark maps, because it subtracts from the enjoyment of exploration. 
5) The multiplayer experience is poor. It is good that I first finished the campains on singleplayer and only then I played them in multiplayer - because the great majority of players moved on to Left4Dead 2 and Left4Blood. The ones that still play rush mindlessly to the end of the mission, so you can't take your time to explore and you can't play properly/realistically - which is to stick together and play carefully. Also there are a lot of hackers and trols. Multiplayer is ok only if you play with your steam friends, and especially if you play with your real life friends. 
6) There are some extra modalities but they are badly done - "versus" where one team play as monsters and one team as survivors - it is unbalanced and chaotic. "Survival" is just the "hold the fort" version of the maps - which is very hard - and only possible to finish with gold medal when you play alongside experienced and serious players. 
7) I didn't like that you can carry only 1 weapon, 1 health pack and 1 bomb- which can be a problem on singleplayer because the bots cannot carry bombs. 
8) The hordes rush at you every minute - after a while it gets annoying. 
It's not a bad game, I had a lot of hours of fun. But the thing is - only the first few hours are really great-thrilling entertainment and the rest is just repetitive grinding to the end. The golden years of this game are long gone (of course - it's a 2008 game) and the visibility is too low - which can be a problem for people with eye sight problems.

[h1]a well known classic in gaming culture[/h1]
The first years the game  out, I remember playing it at internet cafes, when I was just less than ten years old, so often, getting horrified and thrilled at the endless hordes of zombies as well as special zombies charging at me. I would play all campaign missions, and the first campaign the most, it never gets old.

Here I am, currently 21, still playing the game, to this day, for the first time on my very own Steam account, garnering tens of achievements. Sadly, there's not a lot of people playing it anymore, as expected, given its age over decades. If you intend on playing with multiple people, it's best to play with your friends as bot/NPC team members aren't the best. None of them will go forward but they love to heal. 

I will always love this game. But most importantly, I won't let a single member be left 4 dead.

So chaotic......so violent..so **perfect.**
If you enjoy shoot em ups, this game is for you.
It includes 4 lovable characters:
Bill: A war veteran that is like the grandpa to the rest of them.
Francis: A biker dude (leather), with a mustache. 
Zoey: A girl with a red jacket and gray sweats. (appears to use Chell's face from Portal 2)
Louis: A office worker, now turned commando with the zombie apocalypse.
Have fun, and top those leaderboards!

Left 4 Dead:

Gameplay: We are introduced to a group of survivors who are trying to survive an apocalypse, William "Bill" Overbeck: a veteran of the Vietnam War, Francis: A motorcyclist from the "Legion of Hell", Zoey: she likes them police movies and would like to be just like his father and Luis: A systems analyst in "Franklin Brothers" in the IT department in Philadelphia. These survivors experienced the apocalypse, which only happened in two weeks. Its objective is to cross the entire United States. to arrive with the military and be rescued... "But luck will not be with them".

Includes modes such as: Campaign, Survival and versus or confrontation.

Achievements: Achievements are related to the campaign based on the player's progress, including modes such as: versus and survival.

Soundtrack: The main menu has a good theme, the soundtrack of the levels is great.

DLC: The game includes the joint downloadable content "The Sacrifice".

Maps: The maps are variables which count the player's progress, they are very detailed and despite their quality they are well designed.

TLDR: Do yourself a favor and buy it, because its completely worth it for the original Left 4 Dead experience.

Full Review: Left 4 Dead is one of the most iconic zombie franchises of all time. All characters are unique and coordinate together very well with each other. The game is also at its best when playing with a full team of friends and against the onslaught. There is plenty of content to go around for the base-game, especially when it comes to venturing into the campaigns. There are still some issues I have with this entry, however.

The versus game mode can be highly unfair at times, mainly for the infected. If there is only one infected team player, there is no stopping the survivors, and no AI to compensate missing player slots.

Modding for the original Left 4 Dead however is a much more complicated, unlike its sequel, mainly due to how there is no Steam Workshop involved. Even the vanilla modding method (i.e. addons folder) sometimes doesn't apply to certain modifications, which makes custom content a little bit of a challenge for those not experienced in modding.

Conclusion: Be advised that this game also has its content brought into Left 4 Dead 2, but is a much more lazy and inaccurate port to the sequel. If you wish to have a decent original Left 4 Dead experience, do yourself a favor, and PLAY THIS VERSION INSTEAD. This is not to say Left 4 Dead 2 is a bad game (because its far from it), but their port is nothing but laziness and was only done for convenience.

I bought this game around a week ago, when it was on sale for $0.99 (90% Off). The gameplay is awesome, I really like the details and the weapons. The story is okay for me although might be better for others. The characters are great too, along with the decent audio and graphics. I rarely play first person shooter (FPS) games, but this was both easy and challenging. I would also recommend to play with your friends for a better gameplay. It is a nice game, although I will have to say that there is friendly fire in the game but people seem to abuse that and just like all other FPS games, there are toxic players so if I were you I would just leave. There are also seem to have small bugs in it and it is sometimes hard to maneuver in first person. Sometimes I get stuck or I can't get through a door so I have to respawn or try and find a way. A good game with small flaws, the developers did a good job.

I must say this is one of the Zombie FPS games that is enjoyable and overall good than other games I have played. I also absolutely LOVE the part when I burn and explode the zombies with explosives and fire.

 I do recommend this game but with some tips like play singleplayer first and use shotguns/assault rifles for new players. And ALWAYS find and carry cans explosives to make hordes of zombies to go BOOM.

Positives:
- Good Graphics & Audio
- Awesome Gameplay
- Good Story
- Cool characters and weapons
- Does not need a lot for PC requirements

Negatives:
- Small Bugs
- Sometimes you get stuck
- Friendly fire exists in the game which obviously is abused
- You have normal walking speed in the game but cannot run in this game with the shift key, otherwise it will just slow you down. You will just have to play without using the shift key.

Neutral:
- Worth the price if it's on sale

Total rating:
7.5/10

Left 4 Dead is a heart-pounding adrenaline rush that thrusts players into a world overrun by hordes of ravenous zombies. The game's hallmark cooperative gameplay brings together four survivors, each with unique skills and personalities, fostering a sense of camaraderie as they fight to survive.

What sets Left 4 Dead apart is its dynamic and intense gameplay. The AI Director creates a constantly evolving experience, ensuring that no two playthroughs are the same. From the strategic use of limited resources to the teamwork required to fend off waves of infected, the game instills a sense of urgency and cooperation, making every moment a thrilling challenge.

The game's iconic 'campaign' structure offers multiple scenarios with different routes, encouraging replayability and ensuring that players are always on their toes. Additionally, the Versus mode, where players can take on the roles of both survivors and the infected, adds an extra layer of excitement and strategic depth.

Left 4 Dead's lasting appeal lies in its replay value and the seamless integration of cooperative gameplay with intense zombie action. Its legacy continues to endure, showcasing the sheer thrill and excitement of surviving against the odds in a post-apocalyptic world.

[b] > Be me, hardcore gamer üéÆ
> Hear about Left 4 Dead, think it's just another zombie shooter
> Decide to give it a shot because why not

> First level, it's all calm and chill
> Suddenly, the horde comes charging in
> Panic.exe
> Friends screaming on voice chat, chaos everywhere
> Accidentally shoot each other more than the zombies üòÖ

> Get to the safe room, barely alive
> "10/10, would accidentally shoot friends again" üëè

> Next level, encounter the Witch
> One friend: "Hey guys, watch this"
> Proceeds to startle the Witch
> Immediate regret
> Witch unleashes her fury
> Party wipe in seconds

> Respawn in the safe room
> Everyone laughing their asses off
> "11/10, best horror comedy simulator" üòÇ

> Reach the finale, swarmed by special infected

[i] [Scene opens in a dimly lit room with eerie green lighting. The camera focuses on a Special Infected, a Boomer, sitting behind a desk, dressed in a tattered suit. The Boomer stares blankly at the camera.]

Interviewer (off-screen): So, Mr. Boomer, can you tell us your thoughts on Left 4 Dead?

Boomer: [slightly gurgling] Well, Left 4 Dead is quite the masterpiece, you know. It really brings out the best in all of us, Special Infected.

Interviewer: How so?

Boomer: [leans forward, trying to look serious] You see, in this game, we get to showcase our unique talents. For instance, I get to vomit on survivors, covering them in bile. It's like a Picasso painting, but with bodily fluids.

Interviewer: That's one way to put it. What about the other Special Infected?

Boomer: Oh, the Smoker? He's like the world's worst magician. He just sits in the shadows, waiting to "wow" the survivors with his tongue trick. And when he finally gets his chance, it's like, "Ta-da! You're choking now!" Classic.

Interviewer: And the Hunter?

Boomer: [chuckles] The Hunter, well, he's the life of the party. He leaps across rooftops, pounces on survivors, and does a little dance on their faces. It's a real thriller.

Interviewer: Any favorite memories from the game?

Boomer: [nostalgically] Oh, there was this one time when we all teamed up, the Boomer, the Smoker, the Hunter, the Witch... We formed a boy band. We called ourselves "Infectious Harmony." We even recorded a single. But, sadly, it never made it to the charts.

Interviewer: That sounds... interesting. What's your take on the survivors?

Boomer: [smirking] Ah, those survivors. They're like the tourists of the zombie apocalypse. Always stumbling around, making noise, and shooting everything that moves. They never appreciate our efforts to bring a little chaos into their lives.

Interviewer: Any final thoughts on Left 4 Dead?

Boomer: [pauses, pondering] Well, if you're looking for a game that lets you explore the art of surprise and teamwork, Left 4 Dead is your ticket. And remember, as Special Infected, we're just misunderstood artists trying to brighten up the apocalypse.

[The camera fades out as the Boomer lets out a guttural laugh, leaving us with a strange mix of amusement and unease, much like the game itself.] [/i]

You can find some truly unique and fascinating characters in this game online. One of my favourite recollections was of a charming individual who turned rogue, incapacitated myself and fellow team-mates in the saferoom, set us all on fire with a molotov cocktail and proceeded to confess their love of midget porn to us all while admitting to never having lifted a finger at work for 20 years due to some form of combustion which would occur in their pants while they were at work. After having professed their Love for us all as we were now considered "Family", I mused if some people had that perspective on how to treat others, how much could be explained on the current state of the world at present. I thoroughly recommend getting this delightful game and experiencing the online options for yourself.

Cheers to the unlikely heroes of the cooperative zombie thriller

For the most part I do not consider myself a real online gamer but every now and then one get's me hooked. It started back in the 90s with Unreal Tournament, followed by games like World Of Warcraft, Rainbow Six Siege etc.

Left 4 Dead surely belongs to that list aswell. Some of the most fun I had while gaming was with this game, only to be exceeded by Left 4 Dead 2 a year later. 
The late 2000's were also a pretty good time in my life so nostalgia has a big impact. Also, there weren't as many co-op games like L4D in which you play with 3 others and try to survive. 

It is clear to see how special L4D is if you compare it to Back4Blood, which came out 13 years later. Aside from maybe the graphics, L4D is the better game. The maps, the atmosphere, even the A.I. and physics are better in L4D.

Back4Blood may have tons of guns and ways to keep playing the game, L4D did not need any of that. Will you spend more time playing Back4Blood? Maybe... but it's all bland and boring and you keep asking yourself why you keep playing, just like most (online) games these days.

[h1] [b] [i] Valve‚Äôs trendsetter you won‚Äôt ever get tired of [/i] [/b] [/h1]

[h1] [b] [i] ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ [/i] [/b] [/h1]

The first Left 4 Dead, while arguably not as famous as its sequel, deserves its rightful place in gaming hall of fame for the immense impact on the field of co-op shooters it had. While not the biggest or most expansive game in the genre, its qualities are still apparent a decade and a half after its original release, as evidenced by its dedicated player-base that continuously come back to it and one which often beats its contemporary copy-cats such as Back 4 Blood. That is a true testament to the kind of behemoth Valve created.

[h1] [i] ‚ÄúThese things are like a brush fire: they don't discriminate. They just burn up every damn thing in their way.

I'll tell you what: if the meek inherit the earth after this, they'd better get a whole hell of a lot better at killin'.‚Äù [/i] [/h1]

Left 4 Dead is not a complex game. It‚Äôs one of those titles that doesn‚Äôt offer a whole lot of content but the content it does offer is delivered flawlessly. Thanks to their new technology, the AI director, the developers were also able to make this content endlessly enjoyable by making each playthrough randomized and adapted to your individual play-style by altering frequency and aggressiveness of the zombies. This, along with its endless modding potential is what makes Left 4 Dead as beloved as it is.

Additionally, the gameplay, animations and graphics still hold up surprisingly well after all these years. The Source engine simply never disappoints, and it both creates visually impressive environments that are a joy to look at and also allows for an amazing atmosphere and lighting that perfectly undertone the different scenarios you can find yourself in while going through different maps. The gameplay is incredibly smooth, responsive and satisfying, somehow always managing to feel fresh and unique to compensate for the smaller amount of weapons you can use. 

In short, if you are reading this, you are most likely familiar with this legendary franchise and if not ‚Äì if you ever played anything from Valve, you‚Äôll most likely enjoy this as its on the same level of quality as the studio‚Äôs other games from this era. Even if you, like me, only played the more improved and impressive sequel, you can still find value in re-visiting this classic as it stands really well on its own.

This is a really enjoyable and replayable zombie game. There are only four main campaigns plus two more added through updates for a total of six, but the game mechanics are so solid and every aspect of the game works in-tandem to provide a simultaneously unique and complex situation each time you replay a campaign--zombie arrangement, pickup locations, weapon locations, which weapons are available, which special infected are in play, where the tank will spawn, how the players you're cooperating with will behave, etc.

          I find myself always coming back to this game (as well as the second) to play the campaigns again, and my hours on record really exemplify how well-done procedural generation is done in Left 4 Dead. If you're only going to buy one of the games, however, I would highly advise against purchasing this one and instead recommend buying Left 4 Dead 2, as nearly all the content this game has is contained in that title as well (all campaigns and characters). The only unique aspects this version has going for it over the sequel now are presentation and certain game mechanics--for example, there are no melee weapons, none of the newer special infected like spitters and jockeys, and guns work slightly differently such as the auto shotgun which will reload quickly if you initiate a reload before running out of ammo but will refill moderately slower should you let it fully empty (I don't know how that works in terms of logic, but it [i]is[/i] an interesting mechanic absent in the sequel).

          Left 4 Dead gets a lot of mileage out of simple mechanics, and I will outline a few which stand out to me in this final section of my review. The horde is likely to be overwhelming to both new and experienced players alike, as the commons can just surround you in sheer numbers where despite your best efforts with a shotgun, you can't free yourself from them. You'll quickly learn that separating from your team will be your death knell, so the teamwork required by everyone is very interesting both to watch and participate in, especially in the higher difficulties (in Expert, the highest difficulty, you can teamkill with just a few point-blank shotgun shells--yes, there are occasional griefers). The finales can be really tense and frantic, as not only are they the end points of the various campaigns, but also death is most punishing here, where survival can be the difference between receiving credit for the campaign or not. All of the weapons have a purpose and feel satisfying to use to an extent (your mileage may vary based on personal preference). Even for throwables, one has the choice between a molotov and a pipe bomb--molotovs excel at crowd control in a corridor or direction (zombies burn perpetually until death), whereas pipe bombs are a great getaway to divert attention away from a struggling team, attracting all horde to its location momentarily and then exploding all infected in its range.
           Among the negative feelings I have toward the game, I will say that griefers are not common, but also not very uncommon in the higher difficulties. Playing in normal, the team damage inflicted on others is very minimal, so one will mostly find these people in Expert (though there are ways to intentionally kill teammates in other difficulties like with molotovs). Some people can be unhelpful to new players, but there are also people who can be extremely helpful, even in other modes such as Survival in my experience--oh yes, I've forgot to mention there's an entirely separate survival mode with 16 maps to reach gold on. There's also a Versus mode. I don't play the Versus mode, so I've forgotten its existence for most of me writing this, but since it's PvP, as you might imagine, it would tend to be the most competitive mode with unpleasantly competitive people. Unfortunately, if you want all the achievements, you will have to play this mode a fair amount.

          This review is somewhat incoherent and disorganized, so I really appreciate if you've read this far at all. Left 4 Dead is yet another tightly-designed Valve game with replayability in mind, and to prospective buyers, the only game I can recommend over it is its sequel Left 4 Dead 2, which I believe is a testament to its timeless quality.

It continues to deliver intense, cooperative zombie-slaying action. Its innovative AI Director, diverse infected types, and atmospheric design contribute to a memorable gaming experience. While the single-player mode may lack the same excitement as multiplayer, the overall package makes Left 4 Dead a must-play for fans of the survival horror genre. Whether you're mowing down zombies with friends or braving the apocalypse solo, Left 4 Dead remains a thrilling journey through the chaos of the undead. Highly recommended for anyone seeking a pulse-pounding cooperative gaming experience.

[h1] Left 4 Dead [/h1]

[b] The Zombie Title That Defined A Generation [/b]

Instantly reviving the coop shooter, [b] Left 4 Dead [/b] was yet another groundbreaking achievement for Valve. Released during an age where cooperative gameplay was becoming a relic of the past, this action-packed zombie extravaganza almost single handedly revived public interest and developer support for coop experiences. With tight gunplay and great sound design, lots of replayability due to a unique due to the creation of "The Director", and well designed maps which were able to be enjoyed in a multitude of modes, Left 4 Dead provided a framework for one of the best coop games ever created. 

The gunplay and sound design of this game is amazing. The guns all feel like they pack a punch, and the different hordes and special zombies provide great atmosphere and sound ques to let the player know what terror is arriving next. Certain melodies may indicate that a Hunter is prowling around the area, whereas other may alert the player that a Smoker is ready to grapple a teammate to their deaths. All of this culminates in adding to the atmosphere of the game, creating a nice horror theme in the world.

"The Director" is where the game shines apart from other shooters of its time, and even many others from today's slew of coop experiences. This system allowed the AI to place swarms of enemies at any given location that was out of sight for the players, and placed special zombies in locations that could do some damage or even kill players. It avoids feeling cheap by giving enough space for enemy spawns (for the most part), and diversifying the limited number of special zombies by spawning them in many different scenarios. This led to the game flowing nicely and creating a system that encourages teamwork, cooperation, and sticking together.

Lastly, I'll focus on the map design. There are six available campaigns, each with 2-5 acts within their runtime. From grimy city streets and sewers, to run down farms and factories, it almost feels like there isn't a classic zombie scenario you "don't" find yourself experiencing. My personal favorite was "Dead Air", which takes place within a destroyed airport. Additionally, with the campaign, versus, and survival modes, you can play through every map with friends, against enemy players taking control of zombies, or survive as long as possible against hordes of zombies. While the servers for this title are unpopulated at times, it is still a blast to play through solo or with friends.

To conclude, [b] Left 4 Dead [/b] is an important title in gaming history. It brought back mainstream appeal in cooperative experiences, with many titles in the late 2000's shifting to PvP multiplayer modes. This title provided a breath of fresh air within an industry that continued to settle for a lack of innovation in cooperation. While it only says I have played 6 hours at the time of this review, I have spent over 100 hours on the Xbox 360 during its original release. I [b] Recommend [/b] anyone to pick up this title!

[h2] Final Verdict: 7/10 (Good) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

It's (In my opinion) the best zombie game ever. I love the gore, blood, horror, and the horrifying design of these people who suffered a horrible death and then became these mutant zombies. 10/10 Love the design.

Left 4 Dead is a legendary game that sucks you into its dark and terrifying world. The post-apocalyptic setting is infested with mutated zombies, but the cast of characters - Bill, Francis, Zoey, and Louis - adds a touch of humor to the game.

The gameplay is fast-paced and thrilling, with plenty of options for single-player or team play. Fighting off hordes of undead with blunt weapons creates an adrenaline-fueled rush that's both scary and satisfying.

 If you're a horror fan, Left 4 Dead is a must-play game that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The zombies are terrifying, but the game's humor helps to balance out the darkness. Overall, Left 4 Dead is a classic survival horror game that will have you hooked from start to finish.

While I wouldn't call myself a Left 4 Dead fan, I am very passionate about this game and the sequel, even to the point where I've played all of Back 4 Blood for some reason. In general, Left 4 Dead 2 is one of my favourite video games of all time, would be my favourite zombie (or infected, whatever) game if it weren't for plants vs zombies garden warfare, yes I am being serious. I love almost everything about this duology, from the gunplay to the artwork to the story to the mods to even the menu design, it is all impressive. Not my favourite duology because of reasons mentioned two sentences ago, but still very much up there. Here's the thing however, one thing I have intentionally excluded from the list is the characters, which are famously what makes L4D so good in so many of the playerbase's eyes. And I agree, most of the characters are reasonable, emotionally deep and realistic characters meaning you can sympathise with them, understand their struggles and make yourself feel like you truly are fighting alongside them in a chaotic post-apocalyptic world. But notice how I said "most". Now I don't have a unique or witty way of saying this so I'm just going to do what every other over-dramatic person in this situation would do, that being to say it as it is but with caps lock on so that I can emphasise my point: ZOEY IS ONE OF THE WORST VIDEO GAME CHARACTERS EVER CONCEIVED BY MANKIND AND I WISH SHE WAS THE ONE THAT DIED INSTEAD OF- whoops almost just spoiled the end of a 15 year old  game everyone has definitely already played by now there, remind me not to do that again when I do another negative review. Anyway here's why.

I don't know if saying that Zoey is a badly written character is an unpopular opinion or whatever, but I do wanna say no offence to the writers or voice actor playing Zoey in the slightest, the writers did an incredible job in other places and the voice actor did a great job in general. Zoey just feels like a side character in an 80's text-based adventure game, so whether the writers were being overworked with 2 hours of sleep when making her or she was made by a 12 year old on a "bring your son/daughter to work day", I wouldn't be surprised either way. But what makes Zoey such a bad character? Well I promise I will actually answer that question this time in the next paragraph.

I want you to consider the other characters in Left 4 Dead 1 to start. You've got Louis, a successful business man with no combat experience in the slightest, and who probably has a pill fetish if the L4D community is a reliable source. There's Francis, a biker dude not used to working in a team with strangers, but is still willing to lend a hand to the group of survivors he has found himself in. And then there's Bill, a war veteran who clearly has a lot of experience with combat and gunplay, but zombies is a whole other story for him. Now try and describe Zoey's character. This is problem #1, Zoey is a boring character with nothing unique or distinct about her. She's just some random person who ended up in the zombie apocalypse alongside three other far more interesting characters. Now I get it, complaining that she has little backstory and saying that that alone is the reason why she is a bad character is a harsh thing to say, which is why I would also like to bring up the fact that she has basically no character development at all, both in changes to her as a person as well as traits she adopts throughout. Now admittedly, this is a part of Left 4 Dead 1's story that was lacking a bit, there is barely any character development in general, but in this case, you'd think they'd go all in on Zoey having the character development, but in the end even Francis ends up having more than her. Zoey is more one-dimensional than a Back 4 Blood character. In fact, look at Left 4 Dead 2: pretty much every character is unique and changes their attitudes to the zombies, each other and the impact of the apocalypse on their futures, something Zoey seems to be physically incapable of doing. Now I'm going to change the subject out of fear of repeating myself again.

Whether Zoey also looking like a really boring character as well as playing like one was intentional or not I don't know because I'm not a secret agent at valve trying to see whether people would care about Zoey dying in Left 4 Dead 3 coming out in around 20 years time. I know it sounds bizarre, but hear me out. Just by looking at the characters you can see how equipped or unequipped each character is for the zombie apocalypse, from the one in a business suit to another in full army uniform. Zoey is wearing a bland red jacket and jeans. Again, I get it, maybe her looking like a regular person was intentional to show just how unpredictable the outbreak was and how any one of us could be in such a situation any day now. Still though, what are we supposed to make of that? That she likes wearing that particular kind of outfit? The plain features don't say much in terms of her non-existent personality or her interests of literally nothing, unless it's meant to represent youth? In which case, ok, but why make that her entire character? Anyway, you're probably wondering why I mentioned earlier about her playing like a  boring character given how the character difference is completely cosmetic and each character plays the same. Well no offence to the voice actor once again, but the actual lines given for Zoey really don't help with character building or establishing her as a human being capable of doing human being things. Also I don't know if anybody else experiences this, but why does the Zoey AI absolutely hate me? No joke, when I play singleplayer, Zoey always shoots the witch whenever possible, shoots gas canisters when teammates are nearby, uses the only medkit on herself when she has the most health of the entire team (usually in the green too) and completely refuses to revive teammates, even when all the infected are dead. As if hating Zoey couldn't get any easier.

I think one of the reasons I hate Zoey so much is just seeing how well the characters in Left 4 Dead 2 were done. L4D2 probably has my favourite cast of multiple main characters of any video game due to just how contrasting they are in addition to how well they go together. watching as Roachelle basically becomes like a mother to the entire group despite clearly having no experience with that kind of thing before, or seeing how Nick goes from being a snide asshole to everyone to really letting his light shine through in their darkest moments is really heartwarming, even in a grim zombie-ridden world. Coach and Ellis' humour despite their worst fears coming to fruition is also charming, making these characters not only easy for each other to love, but for the player to love too. It's a shame that Zoey never got this treatment, sure there was not much potential when you really summarise her character, but considering how much less inspiration there might have been for other valve characters, I know they could have done so much better.

I understand some people might defend Zoey or whatever, well good for you, more power to you in fact. I just wanted to complain about how terrible of a video game character Zoey is in my opinion, and not even for valve's standards, I'm comparing her to characters from games like Far Cry 6 and Saints Row 2022. If you think Zoey is a good character, that's fine, just know I am going to disagree with you unless you actually give a reason or reasons as to why, because I am seriously struggling to think of a single one. I know valve won't see this because they despise listening to their community, especially on the topic of their games, but at least they lay the foundations for wonderful communities to sprout in their wake. If only I could bring myself to give this beautiful game a positive review, unfortunately Zoey exists. So yeah, TL;DR: Zoey sucks.

Seriously. Let me re-iterate LEGENDARY CLASSIC. If you don't play this game ever, here's a knife. Slit your wrists vertical for results, you mundane pleb.

UPDATE- I've played an additional 250 hours on Steam, let alone the probable 2000+ hours I have from 2008-2013 on Xbox 360. Actually re-installing the game after it spent some years uninstalled at home *but I had it installed at my job/at work to play it there. This game is such a legendary classic, in a world where the 50-year-olds balance work over Solitaire, I can balance it over Left 4 Dead 1. Guys, I wrote this review *years* ago and still nothing has changed. It is still perhaps one of the best games ever. 

To put it into perspective, I feel like these days with Escape From Tarkov, Halo: Infinite, Jedi: Survivor, Fallout 4, battle royale games like Fortnite and PUBG, that their scope and size is becoming too large and depressing. This videogame is the apex of what a videogame was always ever supposed to be: intense enough to make you feel the heat of fast pace, dark and damp enough to make you really remember the dystopia, and just the right size so if you want to become a master at it, you can do so while balancing a full-time job. The direct *right* temperature of porridge, this game. Not too cold where you feel lonely like in free-roam open-world games. Not too hot where you can't compete if you lose focus and end up hating yourself like Escape From Tarkov or RTS games. Where videogames were supposed to draw a line where you got a nice 60$ videogame, were promised 3-4 additions, and required no homework to play. My, how far gone 2008 feels.

If you and your friends haven't played L4D yet, you really should give it a try. There is no point in playing the first game since L4D2 has all of the first games campaigns in addition to the new campaigns. In addition the second game also has more firearms to choose from, more special zombies, melee weapons, more consumable items, and of course more levels to choose from. So, if you want to play L4D I think there is no question which game you should choose. 

On the first installment tho, we played it for nostalgia reasons. The game has so much soul, so much action, so many iconic moments and so many intense moments through the campaign to keep you entertained. Our play through lasted about 9 hours, which is just as long as many games from that time. You also get a versus mode, where a team of survivors plays against a team of special infected, cool stuff.

As I said, the game is filled with soul. The amazing cast of 4 characters really gives the game life, you tend to care for them by the end. There is a reason why they are loved by the community and why the cast from L4D2 doesn't come close in my opinion. Game wise, the first installment has aged. The visuals still hold up, the atmosphere is amazing, the mechanics are simple but fun. 

Some of the cons we encountered were slow response times from the game, the hits land a bit later then expected so you end up hitting your friend when you didn't really want, the hitboxes of zombies can be weird at times, meaning you shoot the fucker straight in the head and the rounds just go through with no effect, but this is a rare occurrence. The hunter seems to glitch out and jumps at on of you only to end up on the player next to his perceived target. The player models get stuck on geometry, but this is also rare. Some indoor areas and rooms are very barren and bland, with only walls and some piping, and I think the game is a little hurt for it. Walking from a atmospheric outside to an very basic room with almost nothing but walls can be a bit immersion breaking. And a final con I will mention is that the game play can get a bit boring if you retry the same section of a level too many times. Honestly I love this game, but I do recognize that the simple mechanics can only carry it so far. Add that with the difficulty of some sections and you are in headache town for the duration of a couple of those sections. This is all regarding the campaign, I won't comment on the versus mode. 

The praise of the game is the fun cast of characters, very good level design, top notch atmosphere and sound design, mechanics that allow the special infected to really shaft your team hard if your not careful, and just the co-op game play that really shows you that you will need to work together if you want to survive. Just losing one teammate handicaps you highly, so the care of one another. I did write a lot more regarding the cons, but that's just because I want you to experience the so much good this game offers on your own. So I won't sing its praises anymore then that.

Overall, a very strong recommendation for everyone who like co-op games. I'm sure you'll love it, for this game really is one of the greats.

Left 4 Dead 1: The original, legendary co-op FPS experience. The game that pretty much every other game released in the genre since has attempted (and often failed) to imitate/clone.


I personally closely followed Left 4 Dead 1 before its release on the Steam Forums and the 'Left 4 Dead 411' site, played the unofficial 'Left 4 Dead' mod on Counter-Strike Source, talked about it a lot with friends on Steam and elsewhere, pre-ordered the game, and played it frequently after its release, up until the release of Left 4 Dead 2.


Development started on Left 4 Dead 1 in mid-2005, the game was officially announced by Turtle Rock Studios and Valve on November 20, 2006, and it was later released on November 18, 2008, on Windows and Xbox 360.

Left 4 Dead 1 was originally developed by indie game developer Turtle Rock Studios as a cooperative, Player-Versus-Enemy (PVE), Survival Horror, horde-based First-Person-Shooter (FPS) modification for Counter-Strike Source, with a focus on extreme replayability via semi-random procedurally enemy/boss-populated levels and item/weapon placements. After this demonstration version showed a lot of fun gameplay potential, they then decided to make it into a fully-fledged Source Engine game, with the help of Valve, who trusted Turtle Rock for its earlier work on Counter-Strike: Condition Zero.

Whilst the two studios worked on Left 4 Dead 1 together, Turtle Rock Studios would eventually be purchased by and merge with Valve on January 10, 2008, becoming 'Valve South' (which they remained until they left Valve under mutual agreement in June 2009, due to a variety of workflow and communication issues).

A sequel, Left 4 Dead 2, was announced on June 1, 2009, and released on November 17, 2009 (just under 1 year after the launch of Left 4 Dead 1).


A big part of what made Left 4 Dead 1 so special was its AI. Common Infected and Boss Infected are capable of rapidly and dynamically calculating the optimal route to their target, and can intelligently climb over obstacles, props, etc within reach in order to take shortcuts and reach the Survivors wherever they hide. Hordes/Mobs of Common Infected will also try to fan out and 'flock' like Boids, in order to create a more realistic and visually impressive presentation. The Special Infected navigate the level more like the Survivors, jumping over obstacles and climbing up special 'Infected Ladders' pre-placed into levels, in order to give them full access to the rooftops and heights (Common- and Boss-Infected can also use these ladders). Which all comes together and adds a tremendous amount of flare and intensity to the game.

Another big part of the game was its old analog VHS movie-esque visual aesthetics, lighting, shaders, film grain, movie poster loading screens, and gritty post-processing effects.

And yet another big part of the game was its innovative music and sound design, which includes instrumental leitmotifs/stingers to telegraph the spawning in of a Special Infected (each have their own unique stinger), the spawning of an impending horde/Mob, the capture or death of a Survivor, etc. And the Boss Infected each have their own dedicated musical themes that play when a Survivor is in their presence, rather than stingers.

The rest of the game's brilliance comes from its 'AI Director'. Much of Left 4 Dead 1's procedural generation magic is controlled by a suite of relatively simple AI systems collectively known as the 'AI Director', which consider metrics like map length/'flow', rate of progress/'flow', and each Survivor's health/item/ammo 'score'; which it tries to consider as an average, and then tries to actively balance around by converting items ahead into more or less useful variants, or by removing them altogether.

There's also flat percentage-based RNG that determine whether chance-based pre-placed items/weapons/ammo will appear in a given session (the odds of which are pre-determined by the level designer on a per-item basis), some of which the AI Director can presumably then alter/remove based on the average Survivor scores.

Other core gameplay elements such as Special Infected and Common Infected hordes/'Mobs' are determined by simple timers. Special- and Boss-Infected spawn numbers per timer/Chapter are simple presets determined by the Gamemode (IE 3 Special Infected min/max spawns and max 1 Tank + 2-3 Witches per Chapter on Campaign, 4 Special Infected min/max spawns and max 1 Tank + 1 Witch per Chapter on Versus, 5-7 min/max Special Infected spawns and max alive 2 Tanks on Survival, etc). Every Chapter of a Campaign has a set chance for a Tank or Witch(es) to appear, with these chances being lower on the first Chapter and the finale Chapter.

The game additionally uses a huge, dizzying number of customizable 'sv_' and cvar files to streamline the experience (like specifying the max alive idle Common Infected, disallowing idle Common Infected to spawn within a certain range of Boss Infected, and everything else in the game; from the health and speed of Tanks, to the capabilities and actions of the AI Common Infected, Special Infected, Boss Infected, Survivor Bots, etc, to the damage of weapons, and more.

There's also an internal lingo around the game design of Left 4 Dead 1/2 within Valve and Turtle Rock, referred to as the 'Left 4 Dead Dictionary'. The Left 4 Dead Dictionary is used to reference complex game design elements, game mechanics, internal game variables/settings, etc. And it served as a way to effectively streamline employees' thought processes and coordination as they were actively developing the game.


There's not many negative things to say about Left 4 Dead 1. The biggest gripe most people have with the game is that since the announcement and release of Left 4 Dead 2, there haven't been many content or balance updates. Infinite bashing is still OP.

Both Left 4 Dead 1 & 2 have major issues related to griefers and even hackers, who to this very day will join games on Expert for the sole purpose of friendly firing everyone to death, suiciding, and then leaving, suiciding their character and then leaving when they can't FF people, joining and starting false votes such as attempts to restart the campaign, change level, kick people, kick the host of a local server (thus ending the session), etc. Some hackers in the present even have plugins that enable them to start votes and have them automatically succeed. This issue is so prevalent that it's almost impossible to go through a full public game on Expert without encountering at least one griefer (often you'll get multiple per campaign), thus forcing you to either play with friends in private lobbies with bots, or local host with a full suite of anti-griefing and administration mods to counter and auto-ban the onslaught of griefers.

Both Left 4 Dead 1 & 2 also have issues related to rushers, who essentially try to outrun the AI Director's ability to dynamically populate the world with Common Infected, as well as exploiting the fact that Special Infected spawn based on timers. Rushing can be extremely effective, to the point of trivializing the game even on Expert difficulty, although it can also backfire spectacularly.


As aforementioned, Left 4 Dead 1 is the game that pretty much every other game released in the genre since has attempted (and often failed) to imitate/clone. This even includes the original developer Turtle Rock Studios itself, which has since released two major (largely) failed games in the same/similar genre, those being 'Evolve' and 'Back 4 Blood'. This highlights that Left 4 Dead 1's breakout success was far more than random chance, and that both Studios' ideas and involvement were crucial in that huge success.


All this said, since Left 4 Dead 1 hasn't received many balance or content updates since the announcement and release of Left 4 Dead 2, it's widely considered inferior to its successor at this point. Hence, most people, including myself, stick to Left 4 Dead 2.

Left 4 Dead is a multiplayer 4-player co-op FPS.  Set during the aftermath of a zombie outbreak on the East Coast of the US, the game pits its four protagonists, the "Survivors", against hordes of the infected.

Play as one of the Survivors, either with other players or with bots, and fight your way across the levels to escape the zombie hordes.  The "AI Director" dynamically controls the pacing of the game and which zombies you will encounter.

The "common" infected come at you in hordes, which can be overwhelming, while the "boss" infected are of different types with special abilities to cause you all sorts of trouble!  For example, the Witch is seriously scary.  You really don't want to disturb her if you can help it!

It's incredible how a game from 15 years ago could be so timeless and (to this day) still be so much fun. It's obviously NOT better than its second installment but it is a good introduction to the series and gives some more lore to the story.

It's sequel ported the whole campaign but added more gameplay, weapons, characters, enemies, gamemodes and better graphics. Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (4/5)

Left 4 Dead is like revisiting cherished gaming memories. If you've played it before, it's a sweet reunion with an old favorite.

The heart of Left 4 Dead is still the same, a co-op zombie-killing thrill that takes you down memory lane. The surprises and intensity feel like you're reliving those classic gaming moments.

The characters and their unique traits bring back the camaraderie of playing with friends. Teamwork remains the key to success, and it's just as satisfying as you remember. The classic weapons hit all the right nostalgia buttons.

While the graphics may show their age, it's a reminder of simpler gaming times. For solo players, it can be a bit lonely, harking back to those days when gaming was all about friends.

In a nutshell, Left 4 Dead is like reconnecting with your gaming past. It's a walk down memory lane, where you relive the thrills and camaraderie of gaming nights gone by... RIP

Left 4 Dead 1 is an absolute blast, even if you're not rolling with a full team. My friend and I have been tackling the zombie hordes with just the two of us and a couple of trusty bots, and it's been an amazing experience.

The game's design truly shines as it seamlessly adjusts to accommodate different player counts. The cooperative gameplay is top-notch, and the tension of survival keeps us on the edge of our seats. Left 4 Dead  proves that you don't need a full squad to enjoy the action-packed chaos it has to offer.

Whether you're taking on the undead with a group of four or just a friend and a couple of AI companions, this game is an absolute riot. The fun is practically limitless, and it's an absolute must-play for anyone who loves cooperative shooters.

One of the classics that started it all

Ah, Left 4 Dead ‚Äì the game that answers the age-old question, "What happens when you mix zombies, a ragtag group of survivors, and a dash of dark humor?" If you haven't played this gem, you're missing out on more fun than a barrel of undead monkeys.

First, let's talk about the characters. You've got Bill, a grizzled war veteran who's been through more apocalypses than you've had hot meals. There's Francis, the guy who hates everything, including zombies. Louis is the team's everyman, which basically means he's the guy who's really good at getting pummeled by the horde. And finally, Zoey. They're like the misfit Avengers of the zombie world.

But the real star of the show is the AI Director. This sneaky overlord controls everything, from the placement of health packs to the timing of the next wave of zombies. It's like having a virtual Dungeon Master who enjoys messing with your head as much as your life expectancy.

The gameplay is as fast-paced as a caffeine-charged cheetah on roller skates. You'll mow down zombies with an assortment of weapons that range from your run-of-the-mill shotguns to rifles that seem more fit for an alien invasion than a zombie apocalypse. Oh, and don't forget the Molotov cocktails ‚Äì the gift that keeps on burning.

Now, teamwork is key here. If you wander off by yourself, you might as well start auditioning for a zombie reality show. The fun really starts when you're frantically screaming at your friends (or AI teammates) to help you up while being smothered by a Hunter or pounced on by a Smoker. Nothing says "I love you" like saving your buddy from a zombie's clutches.

And speaking of zombies, they come in all shapes and sizes. The regular ones are like slow-motion zombies from a '90s horror flick, but then you've got special infected like the Boomer (who explodes in a shower of bile), the Tank (basically the Hulk with anger issues), and the Witch (a nap-loving zombie who turns into a chainsaw when you wake her up). It's a party, and everyone's invited!

Now, the game's levels are like a maze from your nightmares. You'll spend half your time lost, the other half trying to figure out how to save your friends, and all of it drenched in chaos and zombie mayhem. If you ever wondered what it's like to be stuck in a never-ending zombie parade, this is it.

In conclusion, Left 4 Dead is the gaming equivalent of a zombie-themed carnival ride ‚Äì fast, funny, and freakin' fantastic. Just remember, when the world goes to heck in a handbasket, grab your buddies, some big guns, and let the zombie-killing hilarity ensue.

A Zombie-Slaying, Friend-Making Rollercoaster Ride!

Let me start by saying that Left 4 Dead 1 and 2 are like fine wines - they only get better with age. If you're looking for an adrenaline-packed, zombie-killing extravaganza, look no further. These games are pure, unadulterated fun with a side of 'OMG, did you see what just happened?'

Picture this: You and your buddies are dropped into a post-apocalyptic zombie world, and all you've got are your wits, a few guns, and your trademark witty banter. The goal? Make it from point A to point B without getting eaten by the undead or accidentally shooting each other in the face. Easy, right?

Well, not exactly. See, Left 4 Dead is like the ultimate test of friendship. It's all fun and games until your best friend "accidentally" tosses a Molotov at your feet. But hey, that's what makes it hilarious! You'll create unforgettable memories together, whether it's surviving the chaos or blaming each other for team kills.

The AI Director in these games is like your sadistic puppet master, orchestrating the perfect storm of zombie hordes, special infected, and panic-inducing moments. Just when you think you're safe, the Director goes, "Hold my beer," and throws a tank your way.

Now, the graphics may not be cutting-edge by today's standards, but it's the gameplay that truly shines. Whether you're escaping a sewer in No Mercy or blasting zombies in The Parish, each level feels unique and terrifyingly thrilling.

And don't even get me started on the community mods and custom campaigns ‚Äì they're like the gift that keeps on giving. Want to survive the apocalypse with the Teletubbies or shoot zombies in a reimagined version of Silent Hill? You got it.

In the end, Left 4 Dead 1 and 2 aren't just games; they're a friendship forged in the fires of zombie hell. So, grab your pals, grab your guns, and embark on an epic journey of survival, laughter, and "Wait, did you see that witch?!" moments. These games are a must-play for anyone who enjoys a good laugh and a zombie-slaying good time. Grab them now, and let the zombie mayhem commence!

I remember seeing the game for the first time at a friends house. The game came out and we already had pirated versions. I had a weak PC and couldn't play it.
I had a fascination with horror but didn't really have the courage to play the games myself alone.
My friends older brother and his friend installed the game and started it. Me and my two friends were watching (everything was in the living room without lights) and man the Intro really stuck with me. Also the whole intro isn't just a promo or something. The game starts off where the intro ends. After that we went outside to play with friends (late hours and we were in 6th grade in our coutry, going outside at about 9PM to play hide and seek lmao) and it really did scare the living crap out of us at the time, reminded of constant witch bs while hiding or searching in the dark. Later we returned to continue watching the older brother and his friend still playing the game, but in the forest this time.

So the game stuck with me since then and I still consider it great even after all this time. With fiends it is a whole different experience and much more chaotic. But with mods? Then it is insane lmao

BEST GAME EVER

[h1]Left 4 Dead - The Original Zombie Romp with a Dash of Laughter[/h1]

[h2]Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ[/h2]

Playing Left 4 Dead is like joining a zombie-themed improv comedy troupe where your friends are the wacky cast, and the undead are the surprise guests who refuse to stick to the script. It's a hilarious mix of teamwork, panic-induced decisions, and the occasional witch-induced scream that'll make you laugh even when the zombies are closing in.

[h3]Pros:[/h3]

1. [b]Timeless Co-op Fun:[/b] Left 4 Dead's co-op gameplay is like a fine wine; it only gets better with time. The thrill of surviving a zombie onslaught with friends remains as fresh and enjoyable as ever.

2. [b]Dynamic AI Director:[/b] The AI Director is the real MVP, orchestrating the chaos with finesse. Every playthrough feels unique, ensuring you never know when the next zombie surprise party is about to start.

3. [b]Memorable Infected Variety:[/b] From the menacing Tank to the devious Smoker, the Infected are a memorable cast of characters. Each encounter is like a twisted dance where the goal is survival.

4. [b]Quick-Paced Action:[/b] The game's pacing is like a sprint through a zombie obstacle course. There's never a dull moment, and the action keeps you on your toes from start to finish.

5. [b]Versatile Weapon Selection:[/b] The arsenal of weapons is like a playground for zombie destruction. Whether you're swinging a frying pan or mowing down hordes with an automatic rifle, the choices add to the chaotic fun.

[h3]Cons:[/h3]

1. [b]Dated Graphics:[/b] As a 2008 release, the graphics show their age. However, the timeless gameplay compensates for any lack of visual polish.

2. [b]Limited Single-Player Experience:[/b] The single-player experience lacks the magic of cooperative play. While AI companions do their best, Left 4 Dead truly shines in multiplayer.

3. [b]Occasional AI Hiccups:[/b] AI teammates might exhibit moments of questionable decision-making, leading to unexpected and sometimes humorous outcomes.

4. [b]Repetitive Objectives:[/b] The core objective of progressing from point A to B can feel repetitive, but the dynamic nature of the game keeps it from becoming monotonous.

5. [b]Dependency on Player Activity:[/b] The game thrives on an active player base. In less populated lobbies, the energy of the zombie-filled circus may wane.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]

Left 4 Dead is a timeless masterpiece that brings laughter and screams in equal measure. Its co-op brilliance, dynamic AI, and cast of memorable characters cement it as a classic in the zombie survival genre.

[quote=][i]In the immortal words of a grizzled survivor, "We got a tank!" Left 4 Dead is not just about encountering a tank; it's about rallying your friends, coordinating your attack, and turning that tank encounter into a memorable victory dance in the midst of the zombie apocalypse.[/i][/quote]

A classic in the zombie game industry. Nothing can really be faulted except for some voice lines that are repeated more often than would be healthy. It took me about three and a half hours to complete the single player campaign on the easiest difficulty. I also tried the multiplayer, which runs mainly on "unofficial" servers. Compared to the second part, of course, a few weapons, enemies and also ways to improve your ammunition are missing. But despite all that, I really like the game and can recommend it to practically anyone who likes to play a first-person zombie shooter. I would like to rate it as 9/10, it is not perfect but it is a great thing.

Left 4 Dead unquestionably stands as a gaming masterpiece, offering an exceptional and unparalleled cooperative survival horror experience. For me personally, I can only speak for the cooperative game mode, as I've never ventured into playing the competitive 'Versus' mode. So, what distinguishes this wonderful game from others in its genre?

For me, Left 4 Dead's brilliance shines most brightly in its cooperative gameplay. The necessity of teamwork to survive is not only encouraged; it's vital. This game epitomizes the joy of collaborating with either friends or newfound allies to conquer the challenges it presents. The ingenious AI Director is a key highlight in offering up different gameplay challenges. It ensures that each playthrough remains fresh and unpredictable. Whether it's enemy placement, item distribution, or the intensity of the infected hordes, it adapts to your team's performance, guaranteeing that no two playthroughs are identical.

One of the game's most compelling features is its limitless replayability, thanks to random events and procedurally generated content. Even after playing the same campaign multiple times, I've still encountered new challenges and surprises. The four playable characters, each with their unique and very likable personalities, add a layer of depth to the game. It's impossible not to form an attachment to them as you fight side-by-side, making their survival just as meaningful as yours.

This game takes players through many various different environments. Within this diversity, it ensures that the gameplay remains engaging enough to negate monotony. The game's pacing is impeccable, striking a balance between moments of quiet tension and heart-pounding action. And the sound design and music score are top-notch, immersing players with eerie infected cries and chilling background music, enhancing the overall tension.

In conclusion, Left 4 Dead retains its status as a masterpiece in the realm of cooperative multiplayer gaming, serving as the benchmark for thrilling survival horror experiences. Its innovative mechanics, exceptional AI, and enduring appeal make it a must-play for anyone seeking adrenaline-pumping thrills and unforgettable gaming moments. Playing it is consistently an absolute blast.

UPDATED: Furthermore, Valve's decision to support modding has further extended the game's longevity. The abundance of user-created content, ranging from new campaigns to custom skins and weapons, ensures there's always something fresh to explore. This, in turn, has nurtured a strong sense of community. Even my very own modded [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/hardcore4][u]HardA server[/u][/url] stands as proof that this game has not been left 4 dead - to coin an apt idiom. :)

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Thank you for all the years of zombie mutilation. Happy 20th anniversary Steam!
