Pretty good game. I used to play this when I was 10. I left the game when my father came home and told us that we can go to a trip in America. The trip was fun. I forgot about the game for the next 7 years. Then, at 17, I played it again, trying to understand Versus a little better and also having fun on random servers with 16 people. It was an ok experience, a little random, but funny. Then, I forgot about the game again, until this year, when my friends invited me on L4D2 to play with them. I played it and I liked it too. To be fair, if you can, buy L4D2 only. But if you want to support the developers, buy L4D1 too. Besides all these, my recommendation would be to go for L4D2. You have more special infected, more characters, and, most importantly, a player database that actually exists... These days, I was trying to go for 100% achievements, but I simply couldn't find many servers and players... Sad a bit, but glad at least they are on L4D2 mostly.

Even though Left 4 Dead 2 has all the maps and characters from this one, i still recommend this game because both Left 4 Dead games play fundamentally differently from each other, and this comes down to a series of minor changes that quickly add up. These games are different and it is more than just Left 4 Dead 2 having more stuff and players.
---
Left 4 Dead 1 generally rewards being cautious and finding safe spots because of it's lack of melee weapons and additional reload animations. Horde events are not endless, bile isn't in the game, and more special infected being boomers. Tanks finish off survivors instead of trying to incapacitate the whole team unless shoved multiple times by a players.
Maps have more enclosed spaces that cannot be disrupted because the game does not have Spitters or Jockeys.
It's limitations force survivors to work together and be cautious. The L4D1 mode in L4D2 does not address all of these changes and often has no players.

Left 4 dead 1 Also has a much darker tone , textures are darker on all maps, game has a less "cartony" aesthetic. Left 4 dead 2 has silly sounding infected and more upbeat music. 

[h1] The Positives [/h1]
+ You can see your legs if you look down. 
+ Free DLC maps.
+ Low PC Specs required.
+ Flawless Lobby/Drop-in, allows player to effortlessly find a game. 
+ Tense atmosphere, creepy soundtrack, Perfect for Co-Op.
+ Really good replayability.
+ Includes remote play.
+ Excellent port, Windows and Mac support, supports high refresh rates and resolution. 
+ Playing with friends is amazing. 
+ Aged like wine, still alot of players in 2023.
+ Group conversations are really fun and engaging.
+ Gameplay holds up quite well and is similar to other source games. 
+ It was released in 2008 and still better than "Back 4 Blood".
+ Advanced enemy A.I that acts like a dynamic difficulty setting. If you‚Äôre having a hard time the A.I automatically eases you with health kits and ammo. The developers call this system ‚Äòthe Director.‚Äô
+ Each map has a movie like poster loading screen, and ends with movie style credits at the end of every map, it adds a little flavour. 
+ Many different enemy types.
+ You can make your own maps. 
+ Can play as Special Infected in Versus mode.
+ Dedicated servers are easy to set up. 
+ Developer Commentary.


[h1] The Negatives  [/h1]
- Many players ragequit and leave after going down once. It's a bit too common ;P
- No workshop, so players have to manually download maps, unable to download from server they are joining. 
- Tons of toxic players.
- Lacks a proper narritive. 
- Most games are probaly going to be unenjoyable (because of trollers), although the player count is ok for a 2008 game, you should play with your friends instead of randoms as the experience will be more enjoyable then. 



[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
I would get both Left 4 Dead games, since both have different vibes/feelings ;)

Left 4 Dead is a cooperative first-person shooter game developed and published by Valve Corporation. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by zombies, and players must work together to survive against hordes of the undead.

One of the things I liked about Left 4 Dead is the intense and thrilling gameplay. The game's AI director dynamically adjusts the difficulty and number of zombies based on the players' performance, creating a sense of unpredictability and tension. The game also features a variety of weapons and special infected enemies, adding to the game's replayability.

One thing I didn't like about the game is that the campaign is relatively short and the game's story is not very well developed. Additionally, the game's graphics and overall presentation may feel dated to some players.

Overall, I would recommend Left 4 Dead to fans of cooperative first-person shooters, especially those who enjoy intense and thrilling gameplay. The game's AI director adds a sense of unpredictability and tension to the gameplay, and the variety of weapons and special infected enemies makes the game replayable. However, players should be aware that the campaign is relatively short and the game's story is not very well developed, and the game may feel dated to some players.

Well, I'll get right to it.
This game is the best one of the two games in the series as of right now.
Things it has that L4D2 does not:
+ambiance
+mood
+color scheme
+animations
+hunter mechanics - bhopping the hunter, rooftop access in almost all areas, etc.
+minimal hud elements
All of these go together to make L4D1 a much more 'crisp' feeling environment.

Things about the game I don't like:  (Bear in mind not many of these are the game's fault - and most of these issues fall right on Valve)
- Lack of support from the developers, as it seems mainly, to pun, "left for dead" in sake of the sequel by Valve. I mean the game doesn't even have trading cards and early access titles on steam that are purchasable Alpha-stage games DO. What's that say? 
- Also, no steam workshop.
- There are a number of exploits in the first game that are left totally unchecked by the default game developers - such as crouch glitching a hunter in versus off of a collision-enabled object such as a moveable car [punchable]. (too many to list here)
- No competitive mode ever instated in the game: I.E. a rebalancing mode that would work much like the Rotoblin sourcemod plugin - removing tier 2 weaponry or limiting them, as well as items and health items.
- No SOURCETV or HLTV equivalent!!! EDIT: There is now a sourcemod plugin that fixes SourceTV!
- Extremely locked-down engine, with SO many commands being set to literally "DEVONLY" tags in the source code itself - making them invisible inside the engine without removing the "DEVONLY" tags or using Sourcemod.
- No easy or simple way to remove [u]all[/u] of the elements of the hud visually [u][Ilncluding visual recoil][/u] during demo recording, for good smooths, for stable recording that feels more 'camera-like', as POV demos can be somewhat messy, and a cleaning up is always in order when cfging, and you must write a config to record them smoothly, ((and while this is nice of them as a company to let us use the developer console, this is the best kind of game in that arena, and Valve has always held steadfast to that for their older games)); meant solely to increase the popularity of their games that much more.  :/ Come on its a glorification for a fan to dedicate some of their time on earth to the personal creation of something like that, and when done right they are very entertaining.

Great game, despite being the first game
Both L4d and L4d2 are similar in game-play, and a lot of mechanics and items are carried over, however there is still quite a difference between both of these, both in game-play and atmosphere.
In general, L4d has a darker, more grim tone to it, whilst L4d2 has a more comedic and lighthearted tone
L4d contains much fewer weapons and special infected, making the game (in my opinion), in general, easier than the second game.

Some game-play differences for l4d2 players
- There is no shove limit or delay in campaign (remains in survival and versus)
- No Jockeys, Chargers, Spitters (Boomers, Smokers, Hunters, tanks and witches all remain)
- The Shotgun and autoshotgun seem much better in terms of range
- The best weapon is either the hunting rifle or auto shotgun (No ak in the game)
- No workshop (so downloading mods/add-ons are harder)
- A few more map glitches that haven't been patched yet

If you're a fan of zombie games or just looking for a thrilling co-op experience, Left 4 Dead is a must-have. Just be prepared to be scared out of your wits.

[h1] Left 4 Dead Review [/h1]
  I originally got this game (alongside with L4D2 in a bundle) because I wanted to try out other games, especially horror.

  The game overall is fantastic and fun - the campaigns themselves are captivating and the ambiance is like horror; like what you see in movies. Obviously, that is the whole point. What I noticed between this and the sequel version is that this one is more onto the stereotypical horror-type yet grim tones throughout the maps while the second game is more comedic and lighthearted.

  I don't think I need to say much more of how much fun this game is, but, for those you only played L4D2, here are some key differences:

[*]There is no shove/push limit
[*]There's only the Boomer, Hunter, Smoker, Witch, and Tank
[*]There are fewer weapons to choose from (ex. best weapon overall is the hunting rifle)
[*]Interestingly, there's a higher chance of a Tank appearing extremely early in the campaign (ex. I started playing [i]No Mercy[/i] and literally the moment I was about to enter the metro station, a Tank spawned [note: I do not mod this version of L4D])
  [*]When looking down, you can see your Survivor legs unlike in the second game in which it is removed (you can still get a Workshop item that brings back this feature)
[*]Noticeably, the game on Easy is a lot more easier in this game then in the second game (I would compare the Easy mode from the second game equivalent to the Normal mode in this game)
[/list]

  Those are just some key points, so, it is notably a lot different in some ways. However, to be honest, I prefer the this game's horror-tone then the second game's brighter tone, but, it is still fun and addictive either way.

  Although the second game has a Workshop, lots more weapons, upgrades, and Special Infected, it is always great to try out the game that built up to that sequel.

  As a side note, I have not personally played Versus nor Co-op in the second game, but, in this game, there's a noticeable lack of toxic players.

  Anyway, just get the game - you will not regret it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Ingredients:

1 cup sugar
1 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon salt
4 medium ripe bananas, mashed (about 1¬Ω cups)
¬Ω cup unsalted butter, melted and cooled
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Directions:
-Preheat oven to 325¬∞. Spray a 9√ó5-inch loaf pan with baking spray with flour.
-In a large bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking soda, and salt. In a medium bowl, whisk together banana, melted butter, eggs, and vanilla. Fold banana mixture into flour mixture until just combined. Spread batter into prepared pan.

[h1] ùïêùïñùï§, ùï™ùïñùï§! ùî∏ ùïùùïöùï•ùï•ùïùùïñ ùïìùïöùï• ùïùùïíùï•ùïñ ùïóùï†ùï£ ùïí ùï£ùïñùïßùïöùïñùï® ùï†ùïó ùï•ùïôùïöùï§ ùïòùïíùïûùïñ. [/h1]

Although the second game basically also includes this one, so buying this game right now is redundent... However, there are many fun achievements you can do in L4D1 that are unavailable in L4D2. I went into versus blind, since the game is dead I made use of the GROUP SERVERS available that play a Versus campaign on repeat with lazy bots and stuff. I went in as a Smoker and dragged a survivor for over ten minutes and POP, an achievements is unlocked that literally says: "Drag someone as Smoker for over a distance". It was very funny! 

Is this game redundent to buy now? Yes! Does it deserve a full on review after I've already reviewed the second game that everyone plays? No, of course not! Does it deserve to be bought? Yes, to show support and maybe hope that L4D3 would come out while you're still alive, to experience (or re-experience) the campaigns that include the OG Bill lol and to hunt for achievements that are, in my opinion, more fun than L4D2's lackluster Bile-requiring achievements that mostly revolve around the worst, in my opinion, special infected EVER: The Spitter.

So I originally got the first Left 4 Dead for like $1 during the autumn sale, and when I got it I was just expecting the content you get in L4d2 just shittier. AND BOY WAS I WRONG! 

The original Left 4 Dead still has an decent active player base (despite not being supported by valve anymore), along with unique achievements and game mechanics/details not present in the sequel. I would recommend playing this game over L4D2 if you enjoy slightly more detailed game mechanics, and overall what I believe to be a less toxic player base (especially on Versus)

Overall, after playing and getting 100% on both games in the Left 4 Dead series, Left 4 Dead is better for if you like a more polished and playable experience in the series, while Left 4 Dead 2 is a better choice in terms of the amount of content you get (both games are included in the sequel), and if active valve servers are more important

Fairly short, takes about 5 hours to finish the campaign (depending on difficulty) but it's great.

The way the zombies act when they are not hostile to you is impressively detailed. 
They all seem like beings trapped inside themselves, just suffering and attacking anyone in their way if disturbed by light, noise etc.

 Some can be seen leaning, fighting each other, puking or just sitting in a dark corner. Such outstanding detail!

All survivors have their own charm, story and personality to, I like all of them. I find almost impossible to dislike them.

The music is top notch and really gives you an accomplished feeling after each campaign. It also plays an really important part in the gameplay other than ambient, you are basically using the music in your advantage to know by what monstrosity you will be attacked sooner or later. It's really fun to play this game with a friend.

I haven't played the Steam version much, but I have played 2 discs to death on Xbox 360. I have also played the game within Left for Dead 2, because that game contains most of the content from this game.

This game is one of the Greats. A fantastic game that brought atmospheric changes in gaming media, as well as setup a new trend in gaming for multiplayer. This game is very responsible for the zombies craze that happened around the time of its release.

I love this game. I HIGHLY recommend it, but DO NOT BUY THIS GAME unless you want to give Valve money. Buy Left 4 Dead 2, it comes with all the content of this game plus it's own content.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing left 4 dead and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. My son hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, EVEN IN KILLING ZOMBIES and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Pros:

Graphics hold up amazingly well, combat feels awesome, characters are likeable, story is basic but awesome so far.

Cons:

Not always clear where to go during a level; I'd often get turned around and forget where I was due to simplistic map design and no real help with direction from the game. It also didn't help that getting to another area sometimes required jumping onto a truck or something, which is strange because normally a truck blocking the path = go the other direction.

Would recommend getting because it is a steal at ten dollars, and the quality as better than some modern games. Get it on sale, even better.

This isn't a negative review to say that "Left 4 dead 1 is bad" or "This game has aged poorly", because this is still a good and fun game at it's core, and one that has not aged badly at all, but Left 4 Dead 2 is infinitely superior. Left 4 Dead 2 has everything Left 4 dead 1 has, but with a entire new story and campaigns, new weapons, new infected, new modes, new items, and a way bigger community that you can play with online (especially if you want to play versus with 8 people). Again this game isn't bad, but i'd just get L4D2 first before you get this game.

[h1]BILL OVERBECK SIMULATOR[/h1]

I know I am a decade and half to this widely popular game, so I figured at 99 cents it was time to give it a try. I have only played a little bit in the solo mode, but I can already tell this game would be a great time with bros.

I already knew and loved Bill from the Dead By Daylight video game. I like Bill because he is a 70 year old man that hangs out in dark forests and basements with a bunch of college kids. He also makes the most comical old man scream when he is tossed up on a hook.

My dream is for the final DbD DLC chapter to involve Bill getting an assault rifle DLC and the  game ending by him mowing down every single killer & survivor (sans Meg) like a farmer would use a scythe to flatten a wheat field. 

[h1]PROS[/h1]

-Bill.

-99 cents.

-Feels like a comfy XBOX 360 Era game.

[h1]CONS[/h1]

-N/A

What I didn't liked:

-the special infected being very annoying to play against

 Also is it just me or on singleplayer, it spawns more zombies? Not really complaining since infinite shoves help alot

Zombie, Guns, Kill, Explosion, and survive together... seems simple enough!

This game is a certified classic.

Every character is on an even playing field, with no perks and no special abilities. Only your skills, your item management, and your teammates are needed to get through a campaign. Characters are memorable and quotable from both L4D1 characters(Bill, Zoey, Francis, and Louis) and L4D2 characters(Coach, Nick, Ellis, and Rochelle).

The gameplay has great reply value. The AI director makes sure each play session is unique. From item spawn of items to horde-infected spawns to the level of difficulty. Your team's performance, skills, and teamwork will truly be tested as you progress through each campaign level.

Community Content(Steam Workshop) is one of the reasons this game still holds up and retains a huge player base. Mods, Map campaign, and Enhancements.

I remember after school or over the weekend me and da BOiz would do a "LAN party" where we reset all achievements and go through all campaigns ranking up the best scores, awesome kills, and funny moments.

This game let me meet friends that I say in touch with to this day... so many good times.

Until now still playing and meeting new people on this game.. every game session is a new experience can't get enough of it.

Over All A Great Game That I Keep Coming Back To!

IMPORTANT NOTE: Do NOT buy this game!
Allow me to explain why. All of the content from this game, all levels and characters etc, are part of Left 4 Dead 2 by default. This means buying this one is redundant. Just save the money and buy the sequel so you can play them both at the same time plus have the added benefit of the new monsters you get to fight from the sequel.

~~~~~~~~~
2019 EDIT:
After countless people explaining the differences between the games, do yourself a favor and research these two great titles. I am sure there is a video out there showcasing how they are different. I personally feel that this game is redundant however many disagree and would rather play the original content on the original game only, not on Left 4 Dead 2. You should figure out which is best for you before buying.

With that being said, keep in mind these games are getting old and frequently go on sale for dirt cheap prices. I think you can sometimes even get both Left 4 Dead titles for about $5 total which is worth it. Then you can install and play both and decide for yourself. All that matters is that they get played because they are terrific and shouldn't be forgotten.
~~~~~~~~~

Review:
As for the game itself, I highly recommend this title. This is teamwork at its best. You literally can't get through this game by yourself. Sure, you can play single player mode just fine since the AI is decent but I mean you can't play ALONE as the game will inevitably put you into certain scenarios where you will get pinned down and die without someone there to save you. So either another player or an AI will have to help you up or it's game over.

The gunplay is fast and furious. The zombies are fast and attack in hordes so you can't really survive long by standing in one place.

There isn't too much story but with this type of game you really don't need story. Just fight your way from one obstacle to the next until you finish the game. Terrific good time.

Left for Dead 1 is good coop zombie (and special infected) shooter. Obviously with the release of Left 4 Dead 2, this game has little extra to offer what is not in L4d2. I would say this game is much easier than L4d2, but still is challenging enough. The game provides different game modes which offers plenty of zombie killing fun and teamwork.

In case you want to buy this game: I would recommend to buy part 2 since that game has a more active online community and contains most of the content of L4D1 as well.

The community is not always nice, so make sure you team up with some mates to play this game with.

left 4 dead is a 2008 4-player co-op FPS game developed and published by Valve. It was originally released for PC and xbox 360 and is the first title in the left 4 dead series. the game is set during the aftermath of a zombie outbreak, and while the sequel is much better, the original was a great foundation for what eventually became one of the best games of all time, especially at the time of their release. i definitely recommend playing with friends if you can, playing the campaigns alone is pretty boring and having 3 AI teammates can be really frustrating, especially at the expert levels.

The end of the world is coming. The dead have risen from their graves and are killing every living thing in their path. Cities fell, and many people simply gave up and stopped trying to survive.
You are in a group of other survivors, you decide at all costs - to escape. And get to the point of evacuation - through the crowds of the undead who want to tear apart your bodies and drink warm blood!

[list][b]Pros:[/b]
[*]+ Achievements
[*]+ Multiple game modes
[*]+ Difficulty
[*]+ Adaptive AI
[*]+ Many modifications and maps from the community
[*]+ Co-op playthrough
[*]+ Unique zombies

[b]Minuses:[/b]
[*]- Unfriendly community in the game[/list]

[b]Total:[/b]
The first adaptive AI game to be named "Director". Thanks to him, the game always floods the map with crowds of Zombies so that the players do not get bored, and also maintains a balance between the pace of the game and the difficulty.
In addition to the classic zombies - the player can meet "mutated" ones. Zombies that differ in both their appearance and attacks / amount of life. And no - these are not bosses, but ordinary opponents that prevent you from reaching the shelter.
Due to the structure similar to Half Life, the game quickly received a lot of modifications - which diversified the game in many aspects.
The game is recommended for purchase and play in the company of friends. And still ready to give you a few hours of challenging but fun action.

I've just recently started playing L4D on Steam, but I've played it since launch on the Xbox 360 and it's a great game. A true classic! In my opinion I prefer it over its sequel, despite having fewer features. This game has a specific atmosphere that I think L4D2 lacks and I also prefer the campaigns in this one compared to L4D2. 

The game is a little wonky on Steam Deck, but definitely playable. Just be prepared to have to tweak resolution and other graphics settings a bit. Also remember to enable gamepad support in L4D's settings menu. If you don't, your Steam Deck will not function like a gamepad even if you have the correct controller scheme set up in SteamOS. I don't have a lot of experience with PC games and all their settings so it took me a minute to figure that out. Hope it helps someone else! 

TLDR; Buy the game, it's fun and a classic!

Left 4 Dead is a great game with a memorable cast of characters, unique mechanics that set it apart from other zombie shooters, entertaining and immersive levels, and addicting gameplay. Under any other circumstance, I would absolutely recommend buying it.

[b]However[/b], Left 4 Dead 2 makes the first game obsolete. It has [i]all[/i] of the content from Left 4 Dead, plus its own additional weapons, levels, enemies, modes. If you like the mechanics of the first game better, you can restore them using Mutations or Steam Workshop mods. Everything L4D can do, the sequel can do better.

The only reason to play the original Left 4 Dead now would be for achievement hunting or nostalgia value. I cannot recommend buying it except at a very low price on sale, and that's only if you are really curious about it. Buy Left 4 Dead 2 instead for the best way to experience the gameplay. For what it is worth, L4D is still a groundbreaking co-op shooter that is far superior to PvE games like Raid: WW2,

Not as expansive or as long as the second game, but weapons and items are more scarce so it feels more like a survival horror game. 
If you don't feel like modding L4D2 to be more like L4D1 (which is possible), then give this a try.  
It's pretty nostalgic, too.

Also, I'd like to take some time to give praise to something that we often take for granted. 

Most game companies will often delist games on digital stores when they decide to release an updated version, like a remake or a remaster or something. 
This is a scummy, anti-consumer practice. 

Valve, however, knows full-well that Left 4 Dead 2 existing basically makes Left 4 Dead 1 irrelevant and obsolete for the most part. Especially considering everything from L4D1, even right down to it's PLOT, is in L4D2.
And yet they still insist on keeping L4D1 on Steam.  

Just in case oldies like me decide they wanna go back for nostalgia or for some other reason (which I did once.)
They allow us to have options even if most people won't choose it, and I find that to be commendable and an example that every other video game company should follow.

Rating - 7/10
+ transparency of campaigns.
+ simple control.
+ character behavior.
+ weapon control and behavior.
+ no unnecessary side quests.
+ variety and randomness of infected and special infected, including horde attacks.
+ graphic design.

- occasional hitboxes and "lethality" of special infected (a hit to the head of a witch with a sniper rifle from close range did not cause death - unrealistic, a hit to the head of a hunter from close range with a shotgun while jumping did not cause death - unrealistic - he jumped and knocked the character to the ground).
- the behavior of the UI characters in some parts of the campaign (mostly the final stage) when the main character uses the machine gun, they do not cover the machine gun but run away.
- do not react to the presence of a special infected (Tank) until it is in line of sight.
- occasional unnecessary shooting at the infected which attracts the attention of others or hordes. It's an unnecessary delay when trying to speedrun.

This game keeps you on your toes. One moment you think you're safe and the next moment there's a whole horde of zombies coming in from behind you. I really liked some of the horde fights in this game, usually the ones at the end of each chapter. Lots of zombies spawn during those fights and a couple of them me and my friends had to fight tooth and nail to survive the onslaught. This game is for sure better when you have three other people playing with you as sometimes the bots will alert a witch that you could have avoided. There's also some friendly competition to be had between survivors to see who can get the most kills or do the most damage to the tank zombie. Left 4 Dead is a good game to pick up and play with friends, the main story's not that long but every minute is a blast!

[h1]Left 4 Dead[/h1]

Considering this game was made back in 2008 it surprises
me with it's unique shadow map design and amazing in-game music
that intensifies the horror element of the game. Everything
about left 4 dead feels perfect and unique in every little detail.
From zombies that have different face expressions when they are
attacking survivors to having amazing voice-lines that make
every character alive and fit into the atmosphere of the game.
The game comes with 4 different game modes to choose from -
Single Player, Campaign, Versus and Survival. In short - you
can play this game by yourself, with friends, Online
(Special Infected vs Humans) and Team survival mode that let's
you survive wave after wave of zombies until your squad gets 
knocked out. For me personally the best game mode is campaign.
There is nothing more satisfying than killing zombies with your friends after a long day. 
Guarantee you will have tons of fun and one of the best memories
with them in this game.

The classic of modern co-op games.

While it might seem a bit simple in terms of variety compared to some modern co-op games, it still holds pretty well and can provide a decent amount of entertainment.

For those who dont know, you are a group of survivors trying to navigate the zombie apocalypse in order to survive. There are 4 people, either players or NPCs, that need to get from one point to another, picking up whatever weaponry can help them along the way. Story is limited, but pleasant. Enemies can be quite challenging depending on the difficulty. 

Good stuff, go for it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Left 4 Dead is a masterpiece, valve and the developers truly put every thing they had into this game. The pure atmosphere is borderline like a movie, the game feels realistic, the world around you feels like something you would actually see in a zombie apocalypse. I personally like l4d1 better than l4d2 as l4d1 feels more realistic and gritty, a lot of left 4 dead 1 is dark alleys and dead cities. Left 4 dead 2's campaign felt less real as the chapters have a lot of variety, left 4 dead 1 has a better singleplayer aspect then 2 but if you want more bang for your buck buy the second one.  I recommend this game as I actually had fun playing and reliving the campaign (something i feel a lot of games lack)

The title that started it all, the original at its purest form. The predecessor to L4D2 was an astonishing release at the time with fantastic design, mechanics and atmosphere which introduced players to the genius of Valve and Turtle Rock. Both games have an infinite replay value, but it must be said that L4D1 is largely outdated as of today as its successor has improved features, new additions, workshop support and countless other innovations... at the cost of first person legs, of course. But if you want to be thrown back into the Fall of 2008 and feel what it was really like back then, get this game.

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda
¬º tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ¬Ω tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¬º tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8‚Äì10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you‚Äôve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don‚Äôt leave them too long or they‚Äôll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

An ageless classic of the gaming industry!

In some respects, I know I enjoy the first game more than its sequel. I can't quite put my finger on it, but the pistols in this game alone (and how far you can go with them) make this game pretty good.

[h1]Left 4 Dead or Left 4 Dead 2?[/h1]
     So to get this out of the way first, most people ask, "What's the point of getting Left 4 Dead if everything is on Left 4 Dead 2?". If you're also asking yourself that, you probably won't need to care for this game. 
     What makes this game so good for me is it's much more minimal, has a more grittier/film artstyle. The sequel loses that artstyle and simplicity even with all the different effects used and cleaner and more compressed world textures. Sure, you can get Left 4 Dead 2 looking pretty close to Left 4 Dead 1, but it still won't look and feel exactly the same.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
     The gameplay is absolutely flawless in this game! Everything is very smooth; and since the game uses a thing they call the "AI Director" each time you play a map the enemies will be in different locations. Making it enjoyable for a long time! I've been playing this game since 2009 when it came out and I have yet to be bored of this game unlike the second one.

[h1]Player Base[/h1]
     There aren't much people playing this game anymore sadly, since everyone has moved to Left 4 Dead 2. But the people who do have this game are usually very fun to play with. You do have your "occasional" child gamer or troll, but other than that most players are mature and fun to play with as stated before. Versus is usually dead while 'Survival' and 'Campaigns' usually always have at least a few servers joinable.

[h1]Story[/h1]
     The story is very minimal to keep gameplay more replayable. A lot of more story-based lines were cut, and maps reworked to have less of a story in-game (and instead focused on the safe rooms for people to read while waiting for others to get ready) because of this decision. But the 'story' that is there, is pretty decent and plays out a lot like an action horror movie. Which was what Valve was ultimately going for.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
     Overall if you're looking to kill some zombies, have a few laughs, and have a good time with friends - I HIGHLY recommend this game. If you want a bit more, guns, special infected, and game modes than try out Left 4 Dead 2. I highly recommend this game and give it a solid 9.5!

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I know it looks like I barely played this from my playtime, but uh, sorry don't yell at me but I used to have a steam account before this one. It was my first game! I barely knew what steam was, it was just the only shooty game that my laptop at the time could handle. I fell in love with the game pretty much instantly! and it's crazy how easy it is to just dust it up and play it even nowadays!! They did such a good job with the environments and characters as well as just the solid ass gameplay. I like that I can be the mom of a team and just constantly keep an eye on their booboos and remind them to bring their coats with them out of the saferoom.

So I hear there's a lot of debate on this one versus the second one. I kind of gravitate to the second one because I can play the same campaigns with more stuff in it! the new additions definitively vibe with me a little more, I'll never get sick of jockeys they're hilarious! My adhd brain appreciates the bigger variety in terms of items and guns and stuff because I can just keep switching all the time  and never really get bored of any of em, plus adrenaline makes me go super fast and that is funny but it doesn't make a lot of sense if you want players to stick together. I like the first one over the second one in terms of consistency and presentation; I think l4d thrives in its simplicity and consistency, the second game just sort of has a bunch of things that felt a little out of place or at inconsistent levels of quality. Left 4 Dead is an absolutely outstanding and fun game even to this day, especially with tons of friends. The basic premise is that you are a team of 4 survivors left in a world where most people are zombies and you have to go through each campaign from start to finish without dying all the while being hunted by the zombie horde and special infected.

The game plays like your typical Source engine shooter so if you've played one then the learning curve here won't be that difficult, but this game feels so satisfying as each gun really has a distinct feeling of impact and control to it that other games don't. Each of the 6 guns all are good in their own ways and can be deadly in the hands of a great player. You have The Pump Shotgun, The Uzi SMG, The M16 Assault Rifle, The Hunting Rifle as well as The Auto Shotgun and your Pistol Side Arm.

The game looks really good for 2008 as it has some really nice lighting effects and models for the time. It also is very well optimized and will run on pretty much anything, even a potato could run this well.

I also think the campaigns themselves are all very good and each feel distinct and different enough and are fun to play through over and over again, especially in Versus mode.

Speaking of I feel I should mention the modes available in the game. You have your standard Campaign mode where up to 4 players play through a campaign and try to survive till the end, There is Versus mode where 8 players face off in a 4 vs 4 battle in a campaign where 4 players play as the Special Infected and the Tank and the other 4 play as the survivors and the 2 teams trade roles back and forth to see who gets the furthest in the campaign and the team with the highest score at the end wins. The other mode is Survival which involves up to 4 players playing as the Survivors in a small map and trying to last for as long as they can before they are overwhelmed, it may seem simple but it gets chaotic really fast.

I feel I should mention the Special Infected as well, There exist 5 types of special infected in Left 4 Dead, they are as such

The Boomer: A big fat Zombie that is slow and very weak but if he vomits on you or blows up on you then he will cover you in Bile which will attract hordes to you as well as cover your screen.

The Smoker: This guy will grab you from a distance with his Tongue and drag you to him where he will start hammering away at you or he'll hang you from a high place, the only way to escape is to either shoot him before he drags you or a teammate will have to help.

The Hunter: This guy can move pretty fast and is small, but he can leap onto a survivor and pin them down and constantly slash away at you, the only way to get him off is for another player to smack him off or shoot him.

The Tank: The Tank is like a boss basically and only shows up once or twice per chapter depending on the campaign, he takes a big beating and he deals out a lot of damage by punching you or throwing rocks at the player. He also can smack cars and other objects into a survivor for an instant knockdown, so watch out.

The Witch: The Witch is a stationary infected that sits and cries and if she is awakened or startled by a survivor such as shining a flashlight on her or getting to close, she'll get up and charge at that survivor and instantly knock them down if she lands a hit and will continue to slash away. It's best to stay away from her


I also really love the horror atmosphere of this game as it really nails it's tone so well and the characters are fantastic and all have unique personalities, backstories and bounce off each other well and are entertaining.

Overall this game is really a classic and you absolutely should play it, I also would highly recommend playing it over Left 4 Dead 2 as this game is a much better experience.

My favorite co-op shooter of all time and easily one of the best still today. Left 4 Dead was such a huge part of the 7th. generation of consoles (and PC's)  influencing many titles to come thereafter as they tried to emulate and recreate the frenzied, chaotic, and fun nature of the orignal L4D but most fall short. Never has a game pushed me to my limits in terms of teamwork and organization, especially on Expert difficulty. Years later I find myself coming back to this and its sequel and I still receive the same level of challenge and overall fun I did on day one. This is without a doubt one of Valve's best multiplayer games. If you somehow haven't played Left 4 Dead- you need to get on that shit immediately and pray you don't aggro a witch.

[h2]Left 4 Dead Review[/h2]

[table]
[th][h2]Factors[/h2][/th]

[th][h2]Description[/h2][/th]

[/tr]
[tr]
[td]üì∑Graphics[/td]
[td]6[/td]
[td]The visuals are outdated, but they still depict the game‚Äôs dark theme properly.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]üéßNarration/Audio[/td]

[td]The sound design is amazing, the zombies sound scary asf. [/td]
[/tr]

[/tr]

[td]Wait for a sale.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1][b]üéÆOverview: [/b][/h1]
Everyone loves slaughtering zombies. If you‚Äôre tired of playing all the competitive games out there, this might be the best alternative to have some fun with friends! Left 4 Dead is pretty much a valve classic, do not let the 2008 release date of the game deceive you. I‚Äôve played a lot of newer games which basically have better visuals and have the same gameplay as L4D, but no game can match the level of fun the original L4D provides!  

[h1][b]üéÆStoryline: [/b][/h1]
So there is a story in the game, but it isn't a full-fledged tale. It's more like a zombie apocalypse film, where the survivors are just trying to get out of town. Because there's no knowledge on how the apocalypse began or anything, the story's primary purpose is to establish the game's goal: to survive. Oh, and I almost forgot the most important part: it's not just one film; there are a total of six to choose from.

[h1][b]üéÆGameplay Mechanics:[/b][/h1]
At some point in your life, you've undoubtedly imagined what a zombie apocalypse might look like. Now you can have a glimpse of it. In six separate campaigns set in different locations, the game depicts the struggles of four characters. The gameplay is straightforward. All you have to do is shoot zombies. Isn't this sufficient? Anyway, the combat might become repetitive, since the weaponry and zombies shown in the first hour are also seen in the following hours. But, given that it‚Äôs 14 years old, I had a pretty good guess. Personally, I didn't find it to be repetitive, and I enjoyed every second of slaying zombies. However, depending on how much you enjoy smashing zombie skulls, it may get repetitive for others.

So, you're tossed into a random area and given some guns and medical supplies. All that remains is for you to leave the safehouse and slay zombies until you reach the next one. Of course, there are tougher zombies who are difficult to kill, as well as bizarre zombies that make terrifying noises. The following is a list of all the zombies found in the game:

[b]Common Infected:[/b] Does this need an explanation?

[b]Hunter zombies: [/b] Extremely quick zombies with the ability to leap enormous distances. If it pins you down, you're doomed unless your friends come to your rescue.

[b]Boomer:[/b] If these fat zombies spit on you, they will attract a horde of zombies. As soon as you notice them, shoot them in the stomach, and they'll die with a massive explosion.

[b]Smoker:[/b] It may pin you down by wrapping its tongue around your neck. If you're pinned, you'll need friends to save you; else, you'll have to start over.

[b]Witch:[/b] Probably the most terrifying zombie I've ever seen in a zombie game. It won't attack you until you approach it, so stay away from it.

[b]Trunk:[/b] You can call it the mini boss. It has a lot of HP and it can even send you flying. 2-3 direct hits and you are dead.

That is all there is to it. The best thing is that you'll almost certainly run into them all within the first hour of playing. There's no doubting that it's one of the finest games ever produced, and the fact that it's still working like a charm a decade later proves it.

[b][h1]Modes: [/h1][/b]
L4D has two extra modes: Versus and Survival, in addition to a campaign that may be played with up to three additional people. The versus mode is quite similar to the campaign, with the exception that it may be played with up to 8 people instead of four. The special zombies indicated above can be controlled by half of the players (any except the common infected and the trunk). The infected must prevent the survivors from rescuing themselves, as you may have predicted. Then there's the role reversal, when the infected transform into survivors and vice versa. You are given points based on your performance in the game, and the team with the most points wins. In the other mode, you can confront unlimited waves of zombies and try to survive as long as possible. Valve has blessed us by allowing us to create dedicated servers for playing with friends. However, if you want to join online lobbies, the game's playerbase is virtually non-existent. So, unless you have friends to play with, you won't be able to access these modes.

[h1][b]üì∑Visuals and Audio:[/b][/h1]
The game's audio component is incredible. The audio will only add to the enjoyment, whether it's the distinct noises of specific infected or the nerve-wracking music. I'm not going to lie: the witch sounds TERRIFYING. If you don't believe me, go to YouTube and look up "witch noises Left 4 Dead" and listen for yourself. The game's theme is somewhat gloomy, as it is a horror game. It is able to portray a dismal world that has been overrun by zombies. Because the game is so old, the graphics are a little archaic, but it's not anything that will make your eyes bleed.

[h1][b]üìùMain Pros and Cons:[/b][/h1]
[b]Pros-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Co-op play available.
    [*]Amazing sound design.
    [*]Versus and Survival modes available. 
    [*]The gameplay is pretty fun and slaughtering zombies is a nice thing to do.
    [*]Can run on most rigs flawlessly.
[/list]

[b]Cons-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Visually outdated.
    [*]Online servers are dead.
    [*]Might get repetitive after a bit.
 [/list]

[h1][b]‚úâÔ∏èMiscellaneous Information:[/b][/h1]
[b]Left 4 Dead 2 ‚Äì [/b]L4D2 includes all the campaigns of L4D and also has additional content including the steam workshop support. If you are planning to purchase L4D, just buy the second part instead. 

[h1][b]üòáHonest Rating:[/b][/h1]
The game is well-worth your money if you have friends to play with. I would recommend buying Left 4 Dead 2 instead, as it contains every campaign from Left 4 Dead. For other people who like the original versions of games or just want some nostalgia, I would recommend grabbing it on a sale! (You can also buy the Left 4 Dead bundle which includes both the games.)

Steam: Would you recommend this game to other players?
Me: Yes

I personally play more often this one than its sequel even despite L4D2 having the campaigns of L4D1 because of the insane details that this game has, the reload animations, idle animations of the characters, you can see your feet, everything can be shot (TVs, tables, books on shelves...), The ragdolls when you die, even the way they hold their guns while crouched or standing is much better. I was even playing No Mercy and at one point in the subway section I was next to a water pipe and you could hear the water pressure inside. I literally found about this recently and I couldn't believe they would have added such a small detail for a 2008 game. Just goes to show that games like this one are not made anymore.
Not to mention the fact that there are much friendlier people who take the game seriously because of the small amount of players remaining. I've met many great players with who I've had lots of fun.

Comment:
Even if this game is 13 years old it still has really good graphics. The gameplay is a story where you need to complete a bunch of "waves", you gonna need to kill the zombies that are around the map until you reach the safe zone, you gotta do this over and over again until the end of the story. At first, it may be fun doing these, but after a little bit, it gets really boring cause you always do the same thing over and over, kill zombies, reach the safe zone, kill zombies, reach the safe zone. The multiplayer is kinda dead, there's almost no one playing on the multiplayer. But this game can run on any low-end system, of course with low settings, and it can get to 60 fps stable. I would recommend buying this in the bundle of the Game Of The Year edition cause it cost half of the price combined with 2 games.

Good co-op. If you want to relive the beta experience or keep the gimmicks, buy the second game. The second game comes with all 1st game's levels including the DLC level, The Passing, and The Last Stand. If you buy the second game, you get ALL levels including DLC, and has a bigger playerbase. Most custom campaigns made for the first are unobtainable unless you go outside of the Steam Workshop, and download them manually. 

Modders already made these type of mods for Left 4 Dead 2: 
- You can see below your torso
- Beta levels including beta survivors, beta weapons, and how dark it is. 
- There's a mutation called "L4D1 Coop" that removes newer special infected, keeps L4D1 styled infected, and exactly plays as how the first game should
- Infinite melee bashing
- Color corrections for all levels
- Beta sounds and L4D1 styled sounds
- L4D1-styled HUD including splash screens

If you get this first game, it will NOT come with The Last Stand. That's included in the second game. All the newer mutations are included in the second.

Before I get into my boring little story, I'm going to say that I wholeheartedly recommend Left 4 Dead to anyone interested. The sequel is great, but so is this, in its own ways.

About 12 years ago (going back from 2022), I was visiting a second-hand shop when I stumbled upon a selection of 4 console titles. They were pretty cheap, so I bought the two most interesting ones. Left 4 Dead being one of them. Outside of a couple minute long test run, the game would continue to sit on the shelf for a couple months before I'd actually take a proper crack at it.

After I finished my first playthrough of No Mercy, I was hooked. Spent hours upon hours playing the game. Some time later, when I finally got a proper game-capable PC, I knew I had to get this game. To this day I still play it every now and then. I genuinely did not expect to get so much single player mileage out of Left 4 Dead, but here we are.

Your goal is to get to a place where someone will pick you up by helicopter, boat, plane or armored personnel carrier and take you to safety.
Intro perfectly captures the atmosphere and introduces the four characters, and the whole game looks like an old school zombie movie. Apart from you and the three unknown people, there is no one to help you with the hordes of infected human debris, which evokes quite depressing feelings.

Almost every level starts behind closed doors. These shelters contain ammunition, sometimes first aid kits and, in the later stages of the campaign, better weapons. Until you leave this room, you are completely safe. If any infections are visible through the small window in the door, it's a good idea to fire them from here before you start exploring the area. After a few steps outside, hell begins. Crowds of the infected begin to sprint from all sides and the main weapon flies one bullet after another. From the very beginning, the issue of life and death has been the close cooperation between all four characters. The design of the game places great emphasis on the fact that once someone walks away a little, they are in great danger. When the first horde hits him, the player himself still has a chance if he climbs into a dead end or behind a door and a furious crowd attacks him from only one direction.
When you run away from the slime, which will make you vomit and stick out your tongue, you are trying to survive in this B-movie zombie apocalypse.

I was not interested in the game, but I give a positive rating, because it is the predecessor of games like Dying Light, and thus I show support for this genre. [b] 10% [/b]

This game pretty much set the groundwork for what would become yet another one of Valve's best franchises.

It's impressive to me how such a simple idea, which was to take the Source engine and build a survival-horror-FPS game on top of it, managed to be so unique and done in such a charming way. This cast of characters, though not my favorite compared to its sequel, is a blast to listen to banter, and experiencing their dialogue and their story is in part what makes the game worth it to me.

However, I have to admit that everything this game did was done better by its sequel. This game is worth playing, don't get me wrong, but I think the best way to experience Left 4 Dead is to play Left 4 Dead 2.

Game is AWESOME like it always was. It's important to know BEFORE BUYING that this entire game is INCLUDED in Left 4 Dead 2's "LFD1 Mode" at the same price so you can get both games  in Left 4 Dead 2 (which is where most of the easier mod support is). However, with how cheap they are I recommend buying both. There are differences in horde spawning mechanics/special zombs and a difference in weapon availability that LFD2's version of LFD gameplay doesn't account for which I notice when I play. If you want the grittier, scarier OG LFD and notice subtle differences; buy both separately. If you don't care and you just want to play mow down the undead modded to minions while you play as Goku with your friends just buy L4D2 and save some money. but overall, you know what you're looking at, youve probably played it already. So why haven't you done one of the 2 options already lol. This is a staple in a true zombie FPS fans library.

You are  probably thinking, ‚ÄúWhy should I buy the original Left4Dead when Left4Dead2 is the exact same price and comes with far more features? It has all of the maps, weapons and characters of the first game. Hell, it even has a Left4Dead1 mode.‚Äù This is a completely fair series of questions, but before those questions are answered it should be made clear that this review is encouraging the buying of both games. The Left4Dead games are the best games in their genre and obscenely cheap (1 USD each) during Steam sales. These games are different and it is more than just Left4Dead2 having more stuff and players. 

The campaigns for both Left4Dead games play fundamentally differently from each other and this comes down to a series of minor changes that quickly add up. The campaign of Left4Dead1 generally rewards being cautious and finding safe spots because of its lack of melee weapons and additional reload animations. Changes that further establish this include horde events not being endless, bile not being in the game, and more special infected being boomers. Tanks finish off survivors instead of trying to incapacitate the whole team unless shoved multiple times by a players and maps have more enclosed spaces that cannot be disrupted because the game does not have Spitters or Jockeys. Left4Dead1 can be fairly described as a game of shooting and shoving while backed against a wall but that can be enjoyable in its own way. Its limitations force survivors to work together and be cautious. The Left4Dead1 mode in Left4Dead2 does not address all of these changes and often has no players. 

Left4Dead1 Versus places more emphasis on the common infected by having the only special infected be the Boomer, Smoker and Hunter. This makes versus more focused and not just a game about who can best use the Charger to instakill players. Left4Dead1 Versus games see less rage quits as they are less of a game of chance and more of a team game. Left4Dead1 has a better versus mode as it only has the special infected that rely on the support of the common infected to do damage and distract players. 

The two Left4Dead games play completely differently, but both are good for different reasons. Left4Dead2 is a fast paced action game that often demands that the survivors are always moving and often out in the open. Meanwhile, Left4Dead1 is a better horror-survival game that rewards survivors for being slow and cautious. This gameplay difference is intentional as the aesthetic of both games match their gameplay.   Left4Dead1 takes itself more seriously and has a much darker tone. Textures are darker on all maps, and the game has a less ‚Äúcartoony‚Äù aesthetic. Left4Dead2 has silly sounding infected, more upbeat music,silly scenarios and silly weapons. This aesthetic different also manifests in the trailers of both games. Left4Dead1 and Left4Dead2 excel at what they do and you should get both.
